This system offers a cost-effective solution for aligning contemporary nuclear computers with the varied types of data encountered.", "named_entities": ["CAMAC", "gamma-camera", "nuclear medicine", "electrocardiogram"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Spx, an ArsC (arsenate reductase) family member, is a global transcriptional regulator of the microbial stress response and is highly conserved amongst Gram-positive bacteria. Bacillus subtilis Spx protein exerts positive and negative control of transcription through its interaction with the C-terminal domain of the RNA polymerase (RNAP) alpha subunit (alphaCTD). Spx activates trxA (thioredoxin) and trxB (thioredoxin reductase) in response to thiol stress, and bears an N-terminal C10XXC13 redox disulfide center that is oxidized in active Spx.'

original_corpus: 'Sterile inflammation is a central element in liver diseases. The immune response following injurious stimuli involves hepatic infiltration of neutrophils and monocytes. Neutrophils are major effectors of liver inflammation, rapidly recruited to sites of inflammation, and can augment the recruitment of other leukocytes. The NLRP3 inflammasome has been increasingly implicated in severe liver inflammation, fibrosis, and cell death. In this study, the role of NLRP3 activation in neutrophils during liver inflammation and fibrosis was investigated. Mouse models with neutrophil-specific expression of mutant NLRP3 were developed. Mutant mice develop severe liver inflammation and lethal autoinflammation phenocopying mice with a systemic expression of mutant NLRP3. NLRP3 activation in neutrophils leads to a pro-inflammatory cytokine and chemokine profile in the liver, infiltration by neutrophils and macrophages, and an increase in cell death. Furthermore, mutant mice develop liver fibrosis associated with increased expression of pro-fibrogenic genes. Taken together, the present work demonstrates how neutrophils, driven by the NLRP3 inflammasome, coordinate other inflammatory myeloid cells in the liver, and propagate the inflammatory response in the context of inflammation-driven fibrosis.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Sterile inflammation plays a pivotal role in the pathology of liver diseases, characterized by an immune reaction that includes the infiltration of neutrophils and monocytes into the liver. Neutrophils, key players in liver inflammation, are quickly drawn to inflammation sites and enhance the attraction of additional leukocytes. The involvement of the NLRP3 inflammasome in serious liver inflammation, fibrosis, and cellular mortality has become more evident. This research examined how the activation of NLRP3 within neutrophils influences liver inflammation and fibrosis. Through the creation of mouse models that express a mutant form of NLRP3 specifically in neutrophils, it was found that these mice experienced intense liver inflammation and a lethal autoinflammatory condition that mirrors the effects seen in mice with a systemic expression of the mutant NLRP3. Activation of NLRP3 in neutrophils initiates a pro-inflammatory cytokine and chemokine environment in the liver, leading to further infiltration by neutrophils and macrophages, and heightened cellular death. Additionally, these mice showed signs of liver fibrosis, marked by an upsurge in pro-fibrogenic gene expression. Overall, this study highlights the critical function of neutrophils, mobilized by the NLRP3 inflammasome, in rallying other myeloid inflammatory cells within the liver and advancing the inflammation that contributes to fibrosis.", "named_entities": ["NLRP3 inflammasome", "neutrophils", "liver inflammation", "fibrosis", "pro-inflammatory cytokine", "chemokine", "pro-fibrogenic genes"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Novel techniques have been developed to image cells at cellular and subcellular levels. They allow images to be analyzed with ultra-high resolution, in 2D and/or 3D. Several of these tools have been tested on cytology specimens demonstrating emerging applications that are likely to change the field of cytopathology. This review covers several of these advanced imaging methods. The use of optical coherence tomography to perform optical biopsies during endoscopic ultrasound procedures or visualize cells within effusion samples is discussed. The potential for quantitative phase microscopy to accurately screen Pap test slides or resolve indeterminate diagnoses in urine cytology is reviewed. The article also examines the application of 3D cytology using LuCED for lung cancer detection in sputum samples and the feasibility of imaging flow and mass cytometry to measure multiple biomarkers at the single cell level. Although these novel technologies have great potential, further research is necessary to validate their routine use in cytopathology practice.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Recent advancements have led to the creation of techniques capable of imaging cells with exceptional detail at both the cellular and subcellular scales. These technologies enable the analysis of images with unprecedentedly high resolution, either in two dimensions (2D) or three dimensions (3D). Many of these innovative tools have been applied to cytology samples, showcasing potential uses that could significantly alter the field of cytopathology. This article reviews a number of these sophisticated imaging strategies. It discusses how optical coherence tomography can be utilized to conduct optical biopsies during endoscopic ultrasound interventions or to examine cells in effusion specimens. It also explores the ability of quantitative phase microscopy to efficiently screen Pap smear slides or to clarify uncertain findings in urine cytology. Additionally, the review delves into the use of 3D cytology with LuCED for the identification of lung cancer in sputum specimens, and it evaluates the prospects of using imaging flow and mass cytometry to analyze numerous biomarkers at the level of individual cells. While these cutting-edge techniques show immense promise, additional studies are required to confirm their practicality for regular application in the practice of cytopathology.", "named_entities": ["optical coherence tomography", "quantitative phase microscopy", "Pap test", "LuCED", "3D cytology", "imaging flow and mass cytometry"]}

original: original_corpus: 'The use of the patient's own lungs as oxygenator was assessed during coronary artery bypass grafting in 20 patients. This technique maintained the circulation and provides excellent oxygenation, and the lungs did not intrude on the operative field. Blood damage as assessed by platelet function and lung sequestration was less than that reported with other forms of bypass. No microbubbles were produced, since there was no artificial blood/air interface. Complement activation, as assessed by amount of white-cell sequestration in the lungs, was also lower than that reported in other forms of bypass. There were no major complications attributable to the technique. Apart from being substantially cheaper than conventional cardiopulmonary bypass, the use of the patient's lungs as oxygenator offers the potential advantage of reduced trauma to the blood and merits further consideration.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "In a study involving 20 patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting, the application of utilizing the patient's own lungs for oxygenation was evaluated. This method effectively sustained blood circulation and provided outstanding oxygenation without interfering with the surgical area. Compared to other bypass methods, this approach resulted in less blood damage, as indicated by better platelet function and reduced lung entrapment. The absence of artificial blood/air interfaces meant that no microbubbles were formed. Furthermore, the activation of complement systems, measured by the degree of white-cell capture in the lungs, was also lower than seen with alternative bypass techniques. There were no significant complications linked to this method. Besides being considerably more cost-effective than traditional cardiopulmonary bypass, employing the patient's lungs as an oxygenator has the added benefit of minimizing blood trauma, warranting further investigation.", "named_entities": ["coronary artery bypass grafting", "oxygenator", "platelet function", "lung sequestration", "complement activation", "cardiopulmonary bypass"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Functional high-affinity interleukin-2 receptors (IL-2R) contain three transmembrane proteins, IL-2R alpha, beta and gamma. We have investigated the expression of IL-2R alpha and beta genes in immature mouse thymocytes. Previous work has shown that during differentiation these cells transiently express IL-2R alpha on their surface. Stimulation of IL-2R alpha+ and IL-2R alpha- immature thymocytes with phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate and calcium ionophore induces synthesis of IL-2R alpha and IL-2R beta mRNA. Most of this response depends on autocrine stimulation by IL-2. IL-1 synergizes with IL-2 to induce a 120-fold increase in IL-2R alpha mRNA and a 14-fold increase in IL-2R beta mRNA levels. A large proportion of the stimulated cells contains both transcripts. These interleukins do not induce any differentiation to more mature phenotypes. Collectively, these results show that IL-2 plays a major role in the regulation of IL-2R expression in normal immature thymocyte. We suggest that this response to interleukins may be part of a homeostatic mechanism to increase the production of immature thymocytes during stress.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Functional high-affinity receptors for interleukin-2 (IL-2R) consist of three transmembrane proteins: IL-2R alpha, beta, and gamma. Our research focused on the expression of the IL-2R alpha and beta genes in immature mouse thymocytes. It has previously been demonstrated that these cells briefly express IL-2R alpha on their cell surface as they differentiate. When IL-2R alpha-positive and IL-2R alpha-negative immature thymocytes are activated with phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate and calcium ionophore, there is an induction in the production of mRNA for IL-2R alpha and IL-2R beta. The majority of this reaction is attributed to autocrine stimulation through IL-2. Furthermore, IL-1, in combination with IL-2, leads to a significant elevation in the mRNA levels for IL-2R alpha by 120 times and for IL-2R beta by 14 times, with a substantial number of the activated cells containing both types of mRNA. Despite these interactions, the interleukins do not trigger any progression towards more mature cell forms. In conclusion, our findings highlight IL-2's critical function in controlling IL-2R gene expression in undeveloped thymocytes. This interleukin response might represent a regulatory mechanism aimed at boosting the production of immature thymocytes under stress conditions.", "named_entities": ["IL-2R alpha", "IL-2R beta", "interleukin-2 (IL-2R)", "phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate", "calcium ionophore", "IL-1"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Family planning and reduced infant mortality have led to an explosion in the number of elderly people. There are already 300 million people aged 65 and over and by the year 2000 there will be over 400 million, two-thirds or more of them in the developing countries. Great gaps still exist in our knowledge of health and disease in the elderly, of how best to prevent or treat illness among them, and of how to care for those who become dependent. Although the precise impact of aging on societies awaits clarification, governments will undoubtedly have to develop social and health policies so as to adapt equitably to the forces of change.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "The advancements in family planning and a decrease in child mortality rates have significantly increased the population of the elderly. There remains a substantial lack of understanding regarding the health and diseases affecting the elderly, the most effective ways to prevent or manage their illnesses, and the best methods to support those who become reliant on others. While the exact effects of an aging population on societies are yet to be fully understood, it is clear that governments will need to formulate and implement social and health policies that fairly respond to these demographic shifts.", "named_entities": ["Family planning", "infant mortality", "elderly", "developing countries", "social and health policies"]}

original: original_corpus: 'The present study used short sleep episodes to explore the relation between subjective sleep quality, timing and physiological content of sleep. Eight subjects participated in 18 4-h sleep episodes to provide 4, 8, and 12 h of prior time awake before bedtimes at six different times of day in a sleep laboratory insulated from environmental disturbances. The results were analysed by ANOVAs and multiple regression techniques. Subjective sleep quality, calmness of sleep, ease of falling asleep, ability to 'sleep through', number of awakenings, and sleep latency showed a significant pattern of 'better' sleep with increasing prior time awake and with closeness to the circadian minimum (nadir) of rectal temperature (morning hours). 'Ease of awakening' in contrast, 'decreased' with increasing time awake and with closeness to the nadir/ morning hours. Multiple regression analysis showed that subjective sleep quality was predicted by subjective calmness of sleep and ease of falling asleep, among the subjective measures, and by total sleep time (TST) and slow-wave sleep (SWS - stages 3+4) among the physiological sleep measures. The subjective ease of awakening was predicted by slow-wave sleep (negatively) and the circadian maximum of rectal temperature. The results indicate that the duration of wakefulness prior to sleep and the timing of sleep determine its physiological expression, which in turn determines its subjective impression.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "This study investigated the impact of varying durations of wakefulness before sleep and the timing of sleep on both the subjective experience and physiological aspects of sleep through the use of short sleep sessions. Eight individuals were involved in an experiment consisting of 18 sessions of 4-hour sleep, designed to provide 4, 8, and 12 hours of wakefulness before sleeping at six different times throughout the day in a controlled sleep laboratory environment devoid of external disruptions. The findings, analyzed through ANOVAs and multiple regression methods, revealed that both the subjective quality of sleep and specific aspects like the tranquility of sleep, the ease with which participants fell asleep, the ability to remain asleep, the frequency of awakenings, and the time it took to fall asleep, generally improved with longer durations of wakefulness prior to sleeping and when sleep occurred closer to the lowest point (nadir) of the circadian cycle of rectal temperature (typically in the morning). Conversely, the ease of waking up tended to decrease under these conditions. Multiple regression analysis identified that the best predictors of subjective sleep quality were the subjective calmness of sleep and the ease of falling asleep, as well as the total sleep time and amount of slow-wave sleep (stages 3+4) from the physiological measures. Furthermore, the subjective ease of awakening was inversely related to the amount of slow-wave sleep and was also associated with the peak of the circadian cycle of rectal temperature. These outcomes suggest that both the length of time awake before sleeping and the specific timing of sleep play crucial roles in shaping the physiological expression of sleep, which in turn influences how sleep is subjectively perceived.", "named_entities": ["ANOVAs", "multiple regression", "circadian minimum", "rectal temperature", "total sleep time", "slow-wave sleep"]}

original: original_corpus: 'COVID-19 was officially declared a pandemic in March 2020. Since then, our understanding of its effects on pregnancy have evolved rapidly. Emerging surveillance data and large cohort studies suggest that pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of intensive care unit hospitalization, invasive ventilation, and death. Pregnancies complicated by SARS-CoV-2 infection are associated with increased likelihood of cesarean delivery and preterm birth. Intrauterine transmission occurs, but seems to be rare. Critical gaps remain, and rigorous high-quality data are needed to better ascertain pregnancy risks and to inform antenatal and obstetrical management.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "In March 2020, COVID-19 was globally recognized as a pandemic. Since that time, what we know about how it impacts pregnant individuals has quickly expanded. Recent monitoring programs and studies involving large groups of people indicate that being pregnant increases the risk of needing ICU care, mechanical ventilation, and it raises the risk of mortality. Pregnancies affected by SARS-CoV-2 are more likely to result in cesarean sections and premature deliveries. While the virus can be transmitted from mother to fetus, this occurrence is uncommon. Despite these advances, there are still significant knowledge gaps, and there is a need for more thorough and high-quality research to fully understand the risks to pregnancy and to guide care before and during childbirth.", "named_entities": ["COVID-19", "SARS-CoV-2", "intensive care unit", "cesarean delivery", "preterm birth", "Intrauterine transmission"]}

original: original_corpus: 'An open study of 47 patients with cancer pain treated with repeated doses of a controlled-release oral morphine tablet was conducted to assess the acceptability of this drug and develop guidelines for its use. Each patient kept a detailed record of pain, analgesic intake, side effects, and other medications. A nurse observer/clinician followed these patients on a daily basis and kept similar records. Of 47 patients who began the study, 37 were successfully stabilized with standard morphine sulfate tablets and then switched to controlled-release morphine (CRM). Twenty-one patients who completed the study took CRM every 12 h, and 16 patients received a dose every 8 h. Doses of the CRM ranged from 30 mg every 12 h to 360 mg every 8 h. Less frequent doses and uninterrupted sleep were reported advantages. All of the patients completing the study chose to continue this method of pain management and extended care data were obtained from each patient poststudy through continued monitoring.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "A study was conducted with 47 cancer pain patients to evaluate the effectiveness and acceptability of a controlled-release oral morphine tablet through multiple doses. Participants meticulously logged their pain levels, analgesic usage, side effects, and other medications while a nurse observer/clinician monitored them daily, maintaining similar records. From the initial group, 37 patients were effectively managed with standard morphine sulfate tablets before transitioning to controlled-release morphine (CRM). At the study's conclusion, 21 patients were taking CRM every 12 hours, and 16 were on an 8-hour schedule. The CRM dosage varied between 30 mg every 12 hours and 360 mg every 8 hours. Patients noted the benefits of less frequent dosing and the advantage of undisturbed sleep. All patients who finished the study opted to continue with this pain management approach, and follow-up data on extended care were collected through ongoing observation after the study ended.", "named_entities": ["controlled-release oral morphine tablet", "morphine sulfate tablets", "controlled-release morphine (CRM)"]}

An area including the 5' flanking region -500 bp from exon 1, exon 1 and intron A contained no gross insertions or deletions when studied by a long polymerase chain reaction technique. 4. original: original_corpus: 'Posttransplant B-cell lymphoproliferative disorders (PTLDs) constitute a heterogeneous group that includes hyperplastic and unique polymorphic lesions at one end of the spectrum and monomorphic lymphoid proliferations indistinguishable morphologically from conventional B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs) at the other end. original: original_corpus: 'Incidence of epilepsy is 0.3 to 0.5% in different populations throughout the world, and the prevalence of epilepsy has been estimated at 5 to 10 persons per 1000. Scanning of the Ayurvedic classics reveals that 90% of the formulations mentioned to have action on sajnavaha srotas are ghrita-based formulations. Ghrita because of its yogavahi guna, incorporates the qualities of the drugs added to it without losing its own qualities. In the present study Hingusauvarchaladi ghrita and saptavartita Hingusauvarchaladi ghrita have been selected, to prove their anticonvulsant activity experimentally on albino mice, by the chemoshock method. The observations recorded have been analyzed by one-way ANOVA followed by Scheffe's test, statistically. Saptavartita Hingusauvarchaladi ghrita has shown better anticonvulsant activity in comparison to Hingusauvarchaladi ghrita.'

original_corpus: 'Research suggests that family efficacy-defined as a family's beliefs in its capability to manage different situations in order to achieve a desired outcome-is linked to a decreased likelihood of adolescents to engage in risky health behaviors. It is not clear, however, if this is true for immigrant families when they are encountering with increased challenges in their host countries. To provide holistic nursing care to immigrant families, it is important to know the sources of family efficacy particularly for immigrant adolescents when they are developing health behavior. This integrative review examined existing literature to learn about the sources of family efficacy among immigrant adolescents and how different domain of family efficacy is related to risky behaviors. We examined 22 studies on the topics of immigration, adaptation, risky adolescent behavior, and family function. Findings showed that multidimensional sources of family efficacies (specifically those in the relational, pragmatic, and value-laden domains) exert significant positive effects on immigrant adolescents' health behaviors.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Studies indicate that the confidence of a family in its ability to handle various situations to reach a preferred result, known as family efficacy, may reduce the chance of teenagers partaking in hazardous health actions. The impact of family efficacy on immigrant families facing greater difficulties in new countries remains uncertain. Understanding the foundations of family efficacy is crucial for delivering comprehensive nursing care to immigrant families, especially to support the health behavior development of immigrant adolescents. An integrative review of literature was conducted to explore the origins of family efficacy in immigrant teenagers and the association between different aspects of family efficacy and risky actions. The review covered 22 studies focusing on immigration, adjustment, adolescent risky behavior, and family dynamics. The outcomes revealed that multidimensional sources of family efficacy, particularly within the relational, pragmatic, and value-based areas, have a notable positive influence on the health behaviors of immigrant teenagers.", "named_entities": ["family efficacy", "immigrant adolescents", "risky health behaviors", "holistic nursing care", "multidimensional sources of family efficacies", "relational", "pragmatic", "value-laden domains"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Hip osteoarthritis (HOA) is the most common hip disorder and a major cause of disability in the adult population, with an estimated prevalence of end-stage disease and total hip replacement. Thus, the diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of the early stages of the disease in young adults are crucial to reduce the incidence of end-stage HOA. The purpose of this study was to determine whether (1) a relationship among the inflammatory status of labrum and synovium collected from patients with femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) would exist; and (2) to investigate the associations among the histopathological features of joint tissues, the pre-operative symptoms and the post-operative outcomes after arthroscopic surgery.'

Addressing the initial stages of the disease in younger adults is essential for decreasing the occurrence of advanced HOA. This research aimed to assess if there was a correlation between the inflammation of the labrum and synovium in patients with femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) and to explore the relationship between the histological characteristics of joint tissues, symptoms before surgery, and outcomes following arthroscopic surgery.", "named_entities": ["Hip osteoarthritis (HOA)", "femoroacetabular impingement (FAI)", "arthroscopic surgery"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Copper ion (Cu<sup>2+</sup>) plays an important role in the human body because it is beneficial for metabolism. However, an excessive or slight amount of Cu<sup>2+</sup> can cause various symptoms. Therefore, it is necessary for human health to realize the trace and visual detection of Cu<sup>2+</sup>. Referring to traditional fluorescence test papers, the qualitative and semi-quantitative detection of Cu<sup>2+</sup> could be realized by a dual-carbon dots (CDs) ratiometric fluorescent paper-based sensor with the advantages of environmental protection, portability and low cost. In this paper, the inkjet-printed test paper with the best mixing ratio of the two CDs has been researched to maximize the spectral energy transfer of ion detection (maximum color gamut expansion). Among them, the preparation method of b-CDs has been improved, increasing the photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) to 88.9%. The sensitivity detection limit of the double emission ratio sensor was 0.15 nM in solution, and the human eye can distinguish at least 3 μmol L<sup>-1</sup> Cu<sup>2+</sup> in the paper-based sensor. Compared with the traditional single-emission sensor, the human eye was more sensitive to the color change of the emission ratio sensor. The results indicate that we not only realized the micro detection of Cu<sup>2+</sup> with convenient methods, but also provided a promising strategy for the visual detection of Cu<sup>2+</sup>.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Copper ion (Cu<sup>2+</sup>) is crucial for human metabolism but can lead to various symptoms when present in excessively high or low amounts. It's vital for health to monitor and visually detect trace amounts of Cu<sup>2+</sup>. Leveraging the concept of traditional fluorescence test papers, the detection of Cu<sup>2+</sup> can be achieved through a novel dual-carbon dots (CDs) ratiometric fluorescent paper-based sensor. This sensor offers benefits such as environmental friendliness, ease of transport, and affordability. The study focused on optimizing the inkjet-printed test paper by finding the ideal mix ratio of two types of CDs to enhance the spectral energy transfer for ion detection, thus broadening the maximum color spectrum. An improved methodology for creating b-CDs resulted in a significant increase in photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) to 88.9%. The sensor showed a high sensitivity with a detection threshold of 0.15 nM in liquid, and the human eye could identify concentrations as low as 3 μmol L<sup>-1</sup> of Cu<sup>2+</sup> on the sensor paper. original: original_corpus: 'Osteopetrosis describes a heterogeneous group of diseases characterised by increased bone density due to impaired osteoclast. The malignant infantile autosomal recessive (MIOP) form caused by mutations in OSTM1 is the most severe form of osteopetrosis. Children with this phenotype exhibit multisystemic complications, of which the neuropathic manifestations are the most severe. Infants with MIOP may present with pain and irritability that are likely to become continuous and debilitating as the disease progresses. There is limited understanding of the aetiology and management of pain in MIOP. Here, we describe a 2 month-old infant with OSTM1 mutation-related MIOP presenting with severe irritability and pain. This case provides the opportunity to discuss the cause and management of these distressing symptoms. We also review similar cases and the possible underlying mechanisms of pain and irritability to help provide a conceptual framework for the management of these symptoms in infants with OSTM1 MIOP.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Osteopetrosis is recognized as a diverse set of disorders marked by enhanced bone density, stemming from faulty osteoclast function. The malignant infantile autosomal recessive (MIOP) variant, triggered by mutations in OSTM1, represents the most critical form of osteopetrosis. Affected children display a range of multisystemic issues, with neuropathic problems being particularly severe. Those with MIOP often suffer from pain and irritability, symptoms that tend to intensify and become chronic as the condition worsens. The origins and treatment strategies for MIOP-associated pain are poorly understood. In this context, we discuss the case of a 2-month-old infant diagnosed with MIOP due to a mutation in OSTM1, who exhibited significant discomfort and pain. This instance allows for an exploration of both the causes and treatment options for such disturbing symptoms. Furthermore, we examine comparable instances and potential mechanisms underlying pain and irritability, aiming to establish a theoretical basis for treating these symptoms in infants diagnosed with OSTM1 MIOP.", "named_entities": ["Osteopetrosis", "osteoclast", "malignant infantile autosomal recessive (MIOP)", "OSTM1", "neuropathic manifestations"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Symptomatic splenomegaly, a frequent manifestation of myelofibrosis (MF), represents a therapeutic challenge. It is frequently accompanied by constitutional symptoms and by anemia or other cytopenias, which make treatment difficult, as the latter are often worsened by most current therapies. Cytoreductive treatment, usually hydroxyurea, is the first-line therapy, being effective in around 40% of the patients, although the effect is often short lived. The immunomodulatory drugs, such as thalidomide or lenalidomide, rarely show a substantial activity in reducing the splenomegaly. Splenectomy can be considered in patients refractory to drug treatment, but the procedure involves substantial morbidity as well as a certain mortality risk and, therefore, patient selection is important. For patients not eligible for splenectomy, transient relief of the symptoms can be obtained with local radiotherapy that, in turn, can induce severe and long-lasting cytopenias. Allogeneic hemopoietic stem cell transplantation is the only treatment with the potential for curing MF but, due to its associated morbidity and mortality, is usually restricted to a minority of patients with poor risk features. A new class of drugs, the JAK2 inhibitors, although also palliative, are promising in the splenomegaly of MF and will probably change the therapeutic algorithm of this disease.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Symptomatic enlargement of the spleen, commonly seen in myelofibrosis (MF), poses a significant treatment challenge. Often, it is associated with general health complaints and blood disorders like anemia, complicating the treatment process as these conditions tend to worsen with most available treatments. The initial treatment usually involves cytoreductive drugs, primarily hydroxyurea, which shows effectiveness in about 40% of cases, though typically the benefits are temporary. Drugs aimed at modulating the immune system, such as thalidomide or lenalidomide, seldom provide significant relief from the enlarged spleen. Surgical removal of the spleen is an option for those unresponsive to medication; however, this surgery carries significant health risks and a risk of death, making the careful selection of candidates crucial. For individuals who cannot undergo surgery, temporary symptom relief may be achieved through targeted radiotherapy, which can, however, lead to severe and long-term blood disorders. The only curative option for MF is allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, which due to its high risk of complications, is limited to a small group of patients with severe disease. A novel category of medication, JAK2 inhibitors, offers palliative benefits for MF-related spleen enlargement and is likely to alter the current treatment approach for this condition.", "named_entities": ["Symptomatic splenomegaly", "myelofibrosis", "Cytoreductive treatment", "hydroxyurea", "immunomodulatory drugs", "thalidomide", "lenalidomide", "Splenectomy", "Allogeneic hemopoietic stem cell transplantation", "JAK2 inhibitors"]}

original: original_corpus: 'We report on vibrational dynamics of water near the surface of AOT reverse micelles studied by narrow-band excitation, mid-IR pump-probe spectroscopy. Evidence of OH-stretch frequency splitting into the symmetric and asymmetric modes is clearly observed for the interfacial H(2)O molecules. The polarization memory of interfacial waters is preserved over an exceptionally extended >10 ps timescale which is a factor of 100 longer than in bulk water. These observations point towards negligibly small intermolecular vibrational coupling between the water molecules as well as strongly reduced water rotational mobility within the interfacial water layer.'

original_corpus: 'The interactions between N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA), (+/-)2-amino-5-phosphonovalerate (2AP5) and (+/-)cis-2.3-piperidine dicarboxylate (cis-PDA) were examined quantitatively in the neonatal rat spinal cord in vitro. NMDA and cis-PDA evoked concentration-dependent motoneuronal depolarizations. The maximal cis-PDA-evoked response was approximately 60% of that evoked by NMDA. When applied in combination with fixed concentrations of cis-PDA, NMDA evoked concentration-dependent depolarizations superimposed upon the basal cis-PDA-evoked depolarizations, the dose-response curve for which intercepted the control dose-response curve and was subsequently moved to the right compared with the control curve. 2AP5 shifted the NMDA dose-response curves to the right and Schild regression analysis gave a pKB of 5.0 with a slope of 1.00. 2AP5 also moved the cis-PDA dose-response-curve (apparent KB 3.1 X 10(-5) M) to the right and abolished the cis-PDA component of the NMDA + cis-DPA dose-response curve. These results are consistent with the predictions of drug-receptor theory for the interactions of a full agonist (NMDA), competitive antagonist (2AP5) and partial agonist (cis-PDA) and represent further evidence for a population of excitatory amino acid receptors for which NMDA is a selective agonist.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "The quantitative interactions of N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA), (+/-)2-amino-5-phosphonovalerate (2AP5), and (+/-)cis-2.3-piperidine dicarboxylate (cis-PDA) were evaluated in the neonatal rat spinal cord in an in-vitro setting. NMDA and cis-PDA induced motoneuronal depolarizations in a concentration-dependent manner, with the peak response from cis-PDA being roughly 60% of the depolarization caused by NMDA. Combined application of NMDA with set concentrations of cis-PDA resulted in additional depolarizations atop the basic ones caused by cis-PDA alone, altering the original dose-response curve. Specifically, 2AP5 shifted the dose-response curves for NMDA to the right and a Schild regression analysis determined a pKB value of 5.0 with a slope of 1.00, indicating competitive inhibition. Additionally, 2AP5 moved the dose-response curve for cis-PDA (with an apparent KB of 3.1 X 10(-5) M) to the right and eliminated the cis-PDA part of the combined NMDA and cis-PDA response. These findings align with the predictions of drug-receptor interaction theory, illustrating the roles of a full agonist (NMDA), a competitive antagonist (2AP5), and a partial agonist (cis-PDA) in the context of excitatory amino acid receptors for which NMDA acts as a selective agonist.", "named_entities": ["N-methyl-D-aspartate", "NMDA", "2-amino-5-phosphonovalerate", "2AP5", "cis-2.3-piperidine dicarboxylate", "cis-PDA", "Schild regression"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Vasculitis can be defined as vascular inflammation which is usually immune mediated, leading to structural and functional damage to the vessel wall. Our concept of vasculitis has been built around the events surrounding immune-complex-triggered leukocytoclastic vasculitis, while the role of lymphocyte mediated vasculitis remains largely undefined. This may be due to maintaining a stereotypic image of lymphocytic vasculitis as one associated with vascular necrosis, fibrin deposition and haemorrhage and merely substituting lymphocytes for neutrophils. Our understanding of lymphocytic vasculitis may be advanced by identifying the clinical settings in which such reactions may occur, such as autoimmune skin diseases sharing features with graft vs host disease, as well as recognizing that lymphocyte mediated inflammation may lead to a morphologically distinct group of vasculitides, apart from those associated with angiodestruction. Lymphocytic endovasculitis, lymphocytic lichenoid vasculitis and granulomatous vasculitis are potential examples of lymphocytic vasculitis that differ from the histological pattern seen in association with immune complex leukocytoclastic vasculitis. Ultimately, the proof that these vasculitides are examples of lymphocytic vasculitis will rest on new techniques emerging in molecular pathology that have the capacity of analysing the immunological events beyond the current limitations posed by routine histopathology.'

original_corpus: 'The natural ends of linear chromosomes require unique genetic and structural adaptations to facilitate the protection of genetic material. This is achieved by the sequestration of the telomeric sequence into a protective nucleoprotein cap that masks the ends from constitutive exposure to the DNA damage response machinery. When telomeres are unmasked, genome instability arises. Balancing capping requirements with telomere replication and the enzymatic processing steps that are obligatory for telomere function is a complex problem. Telomeric proteins and their interacting factors create an environment at chromosome ends that inhibits DNA repair; however, the repair machinery is essential for proper telomere function.'

This protection is provided by enclosing the telomeric sequence within a protective cap made of nucleoproteins, which shields the ends from being constantly targeted by the DNA damage response systems. The exposure of telomeres leads to the risk of genome instability. The challenge lies in maintaining a balance between the need for telomere protection, their replication, and the mandatory enzymatic processing for telomere functionality. Telomeric proteins and their associated factors generate a protective environment at the ends of chromosomes that blocks DNA repair processes; notwithstanding, these repair mechanisms are vital for the proper functioning of telomeres.", "named_entities": ["linear chromosomes", "telomeric sequence", "nucleoprotein cap", "DNA damage response", "genome instability", "telomere replication", "enzymatic processing", "Telomeric proteins"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Retention on lifelong antiretroviral therapy (ART) is essential in sustaining treatment success while preventing HIV drug resistance (HIVDR), especially in resource-limited settings (RLS). In an era of rising numbers of patients on ART, mastering patients in care is becoming more strategic for programmatic interventions. Due to lapses and uncertainty with the current WHO sampling approach in Cameroon, we thus aimed to ascertain the national performance of, and determinants in, retention on ART at 12Â months.'

original_corpus: 'AIM:To determine whether incorporation of the pH dependent bacterial toxin listeriolysin O (LLO) into the DNA carrier system could increase the endosomal escape of internalized DNA and result gene expression.METHODS:A multi component delivery system was prepared consisting of asialoglycoprotein (ASG), poly L-lysine(PL), and LLO.Two marker genes, luciferase and beta galactosidase in plasmids were complexed and administered in vitro to Huh7(ASG receptor (+) and SK Hep1(ASG receptor (-) cells. Purity, hemolytic activity, gene expression, specificity, and toxicity were evaluated.RESULTS:An LLO containing conjugate retained cell target-ing specificity and membranolytic activity. In ASG receptor (+) cells,luciferase gene expression was enhanced by more than 7 fold over that of conjugates without the incorporation of listeriolysin O. No significant expression occurred in ASG receptor (-) cells. Enhancement of betagalactosidase gene expression was less, but still significantly increased over controls. There was no detectable toxicity at concentrations shown to be effective in transfection studies.CONCLUSIONS:ASOR-PL can be coupled to LLO using disulfide bonds, and successfully target and increase the gene expression of foreign DNA.'

A multifaceted delivery system was developed, composed of asialoglycoprotein (ASG), poly L-lysine (PL), and LLO. Two genetic markers, luciferase and beta-galactosidase encoded in plasmids, were complexed and tested in vitro on Huh7 (ASG receptor positive) and SK Hep1 (ASG receptor negative) cells. Evaluations were conducted on purity, hemolytic activity, gene expression, specificity, and toxicity. The findings showed that a conjugate containing LLO preserved its cell targeting accuracy and membrane-disrupting function. In cells with the ASG receptor, luciferase gene expression saw a more than sevenfold increase compared to conjugates lacking LLO, with no notable expression in cells lacking the ASG receptor. Beta-galactosidase gene expression also saw enhancement, albeit to a lesser extent, but was still significantly higher than control levels without observable toxicity at effective transfection concentrations. The conclusion is that ASOR-PL can be linked to LLO through disulfide bonds, effectively targeting and amplifying foreign DNA gene expression.", "named_entities": ["listeriolysin O", "DNA", "asialoglycoprotein", "poly L-lysine", "luciferase", "beta-galactosidase", "Huh7", "SK Hep1"]}

original: original_corpus: '1. The distribution of intrarenal blood flow has been measured using the 133Xe-washout technique in thirteen baboons 2 weeks after ligation of the common bile duct. 2. In comparison with eight sham-operated baboons, there was a signifigant decrease in the percentage distribution of blood to the cortex, although the rate of flow was unchanged. These changes were accompanied by a significantly increased flow rate and percentage distribution of flow through the juxtameduallary circulation. 3. In a further five baboons treated in the same way, various doses of noradrenaline were infused into the renal artery. In these animals there was an enhanced pressor response to noradrenaline, and this effect was completely abolished by an alpha-adrenoreceptor blocking agent (phenoxybenzamine). The beta-adrenoceptor blocking drug (propranolol) had no such effect. 4. This enhanced response was not seen when noradrenaline was infused into three sham-operated baboons. 5. These observations suggest that the alterations in renal perfusion in obstructive jaundice may be due to an increase renovascular sensitivity to circulating catecholamines and an enhanced alpha-adrenoceptor activity.'

original: original_corpus: 'Electroreduction of CO<sub>2</sub> based on metal-free carbon catalysts is an attractive approach for useful products. However, it remains a great chemical challenge due to its unsatisfactory activity and poor selectivity. Here, we report a successful case to greatly improve CO<sub>2</sub>-to-CO conversion on carbon black (CB) and nitrogen-doped carbon black (N-CB). By introducing fluorine, the faradaic efficiency of CO was increased from 12.8% (CB) and 50.8% (N-CB) to 93.1% (nitrogen and fluorine co-doped carbon black, N,F-CB) at -0.7 V. A partial current density of 4.19 mA cm<sup>-2</sup> remained durable for about 23 h. The superiority of N,F-CB can be attributed to its large catalytic areas and abundant N active sites inspired by fluorine doping. Specifically, the fluorine precursor of polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) firstly performs as a nitrogen fixator, protecting the catalyst from more nitrogen escaping during the carbonization treatment. The number of nitrogen sites is about 4.4 times higher than it is for the N-CB. Meanwhile, PVDF as the area extender significantly improves the catalytic area; the specific surface area and the ECSA of N,F-CB are 8.7 and 6.9 times higher than that of CB. This work provides an insight into how heteroatoms can manipulate catalytic activity and selectivity through the catalytic area of carbon materials with more active sites.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "The electrochemical reduction of CO<sub>2</sub> using catalysts made from metal-free carbon presents a promising method for generating valuable products. However, this technique faces significant challenges related to lackluster performance and specificity. In this study, we describe a notable improvement in converting CO<sub>2</sub> to carbon monoxide (CO) using carbon black (CB) and nitrogen-doped carbon black (N-CB). By incorporating fluorine into the mix, we achieved a faradaic efficiency for CO production that soared from 12.8% (with CB) and 50.8% (with N-CB) to 93.1% using nitrogen and fluorine co-doped carbon black (N,F-CB) at a voltage of -0.7 V. This enhanced material maintained a partial current density of 4.19 mA cm<sup>-2</sup> consistently over approximately 23 hours. The exceptional performance of N,F-CB is credited to its expanded catalytic surface and the increased number of active nitrogen sites, which are influenced by the addition of fluorine. Notably, the fluorine precursor, polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), serves a dual role. It acts as a nitrogen stabilizer during heat treatment, preventing nitrogen loss and resulting in a nitrogen site count that is roughly 4.4 times greater than that of N-CB. Furthermore, PVDF facilitates a larger catalytic surface area. The specific surface area and the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) of N,F-CB are 8.7 and 6.9 times larger, respectively, than those of CB. This research sheds light on the capacity of heteroatoms to enhance the catalytic performance and specificity by enlarging the catalytic surface area of carbon materials and enriching them with more active sites.", "named_entities": ["CO<sub>2</sub>", "carbon black (CB)", "nitrogen-doped carbon black (N-CB)", "fluorine", "polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF)", "nitrogen and fluorine co-doped carbon black (N,F-CB)", "faradaic efficiency", "partial current density", "catalytic area", "active nitrogen sites", "electrochemically active surface area (ECSA)"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Laboratory studies were conducted in solid-phase reactors on a silty loam contaminated with bis-(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (BEHP) to determine the conditions under which calcium peroxide (CaO(2)) would promote the aerobic bioremediation of water-saturated soil. Closed 500 ml solid-phase reactors were operated to determine whether CaO(2) stimulated the biodegradation of BEHP in saturated soil. Ex situ bioremediation conditions were then simulated by mixing water-saturated soil for 6 h before placing the soil in three vented, 2 l solid-phase reactors for 50 days. Biodegradation of BEHP was quantified using four different measurements of microbial activity: (1) oxygen concentrations in the reactor gas; (2) bacterial colony-forming units (CFU); (3) fungal CFU; and (4) 2-(p-iodophenyl)-3-(p-nitrophenyl)-5-phenyl tetrazolium chloride dehydrogenase activity (INT-DHA). CaO(2) released molecular O(2), which retarded dewatering but substantially enhanced BEHP biodegradation. After 20 days, BEHP in the amended reactor was reduced from 20.3 to roughly 5 g kg(-1) vs. 15 g kg(-1) in the reactor without CaO(2). Bacterial growth was favored over fungal growth at elevated moisture and BEHP levels.'

The studies involved 500 ml closed solid-phase reactors to investigate if CaO(2) could enhance the breakdown of BEHP in these saturated conditions. To mimic ex situ bioremediation, the water-soaked soil was stirred for 6 hours before being placed into three 2-liter vented solid-phase reactors for a duration of 50 days. The biodegradation process of BEHP was evaluated through four microbial activity indicators: oxygen levels in the reactor's atmosphere; counts of bacterial colony-forming units (CFU); counts of fungal CFU; and the activity of 2-(p-iodophenyl)-3-(p-nitrophenyl)-5-phenyl tetrazolium chloride dehydrogenase (INT-DHA). The introduction of CaO(2) generated molecular oxygen, which while slowing soil dewatering, significantly boosted the breakdown of BEHP. After 20 days, the concentration of BEHP in the soil treated with CaO(2) decreased from 20.3 to approximately 5 g kg(-1), compared to 15 g kg(-1) in the soil without CaO(2) treatment. The process showed a preference for bacterial proliferation over fungal growth under high moisture and BEHP concentration conditions.", "named_entities": ["bis-(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (BEHP)", "calcium peroxide (CaO(2))", "aerobic bioremediation", "bacterial colony-forming units (CFU)", "fungal CFU", "2-(p-iodophenyl)-3-(p-nitrophenyl)-5-phenyl tetrazolium chloride dehydrogenase activity (INT-DHA)"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Adipose-derived stem cells (ASCs) have been found adapted to a specific niche with low oxygen tension (hypoxia) in the body. As an important component of this niche, oxygen tension has been known to play a critical role in the maintenance of stem cell characteristics. However, the effect of O2 tension on their functional properties has not been well determined. In this study, we investigated the effects of O2 tension on ASCs stemness, differentiation and proliferation ability. Human ASCs were cultured under normoxia (21% O2) and hypoxia (2% O2). We found that hypoxia increased ASC stemness marker expression and proliferation rate without altering their morphology and surface markers. Low oxygen tension further enhances the chondrogenic differentiation ability, but reduces both adipogenic and osteogenic differentiation potential. These results might be correlated with the increased expression of HIF-1Î± under hypoxia. Taken together, we suggest that growing ASCs under 2% O2 tension may be important in expanding ASCs effectively while maintaining their functional properties for clinical therapy, particularly for the treatment of cartilage defects.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Adipose-derived stem cells (ASCs) have been identified as being uniquely suited to survive in areas of the body where oxygen levels are notably low (hypoxia). Oxygen levels within these specific areas are critical for preserving the distinct characteristics of stem cells. However, the impact of oxygen (O2) levels on the functional capabilities of these cells has not been fully explored. This research aimed to study how different O2 levels affect the stemness, differentiation, and proliferation capacities of ASCs. Human ASCs were grown under normal oxygen conditions (normoxia, 21% O2) and reduced oxygen conditions (hypoxia, 2% O2). It was observed that low oxygen conditions led to an increase in the expression of stemness markers and a higher rate of cell proliferation in ASCs, without changing their shape or surface characteristics. Furthermore, a lower oxygen environment improved the cells' ability to differentiate into cartilage cells but decreased their capacity to differentiate into fat and bone cells. These outcomes may be linked to the elevated levels of HIF-1Î±, a protein known to respond to low oxygen conditions. In conclusion, cultivating ASCs in an environment with 2% O2 might be beneficial for effectively growing these cells without losing their essential properties, offering a promising approach for clinical treatments, especially for repairing cartilage damage.", "named_entities": ["Adipose-derived stem cells (ASCs)", "hypoxia", "normoxia", "HIF-1Î±"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Postnatal serum concentrations of IgG2a of paternal allotype, measured in congenitally thymusless nude mice, increase with kinetics and titers comparable to their normal congeneic counterparts. Lipid A, the mitogenic part of LPS, stimulates IgG synthesis in nude mice when it is given 7 days after birth. IgG concentrations at 15 days of age are 6- to 8-fold higher than in untreated control nudes; this is considerably lower, however, than in normal mice, which show up to 45-fold higher IgG2ab levels after lipid A treatment. A thymus graft from nearly congeneic donors of the same age, transplanted at 4 days after birth, also stimulates long-lasting IgG synthesis in the nude recipients. If the grafted nudes are injected with lipid A 3 days later, IgG synthesis is further stimulated 8- to 16-fold. The data are discussed in relation to the thymus dependency of IgG production and the conditions for lipid A stimulation.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "In congenitally thymus-deficient nude mice, the post-birth levels of IgG2a of paternal origin increase similarly in both kinetics and quantities to those in their genetically similar, but thymus-intact, counterparts. Administration of Lipid A, a mitogenic component of LPS, seven days postnatal boosts IgG production in these nude mice, with IgG levels at day 15 being six to eight times higher than those in untreated nude mice. However, these levels are significantly lower than in normal mice, which can exhibit IgG2ab increases of up to 45 times following Lipid A administration. Providing a thymus transplant from nearly genetically identical donors of the same age, four days post-birth, also enhances IgG production in the nude mice over the long term. When these thymus-transplanted nude mice receive a Lipid A injection three days post-transplant, their IgG production increases by eight to sixteen times. These findings are explored with respect to how IgG production depends on the thymus and the specific conditions under which Lipid A promotes IgG synthesis.", "named_entities": ["IgG2a", "Lipid A", "LPS", "IgG", "thymus graft"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Seven wild-caught ball pythons (Python regius), including six gravid females and one male, were obtained from Africa and were housed in a government animal facility in Research Triangle Park, North Carolina. Upon arrival, the snakes were found to be infested with ticks (Aponomma latus), which were manually removed. Four weeks following arrival, vesicular skin lesions began to appear on the snakes. Despite treatment of all affected female snakes with amikacin (5 mg/kg i.m., every 3 days) and cefotaxime (25 mg/kg i.m., every 3 days), the condition progressed and five of the female snakes died 7 wk after arrival. The remaining male and one female improved after an increase in environmental temperature, with ecdysis followed by healing. Physiologic stress, ectoparasites, and shipping may have predisposed the snakes to sepsis.'

Four weeks after their arrival, the snakes started to develop vesicular lesions on their skin. original: original_corpus: 'We have determined that two infants with perinatal lethal osteogenesis imperfecta in one family had the same new dominant point mutation. Although not detected in his dermal fibroblast DNA, the mutation was detected in somatic DNA from the father's hair root bulbs and lymphocytes. The mutation was also detected in the father's sperm, demonstrating that mosaicism in the father's germ line explains recurrence. The presence of both germ-line and somatic mosaicism indicates that the mutation occurred prior to segregation of the germ-line and somatic cell progenitors. About one in eight sperm carry the mutation, which implies that at least four progenitor cells populate the germ line in human males. The observation that the mosaic individual is clinically normal suggests that genetic diseases can have both qualitative and quantitative components.'

  "paraphrase_corpus": "It was discovered that two newborns from the same family, who suffered from fatal osteogenesis imperfecta at birth, shared an identical new dominant point mutation. Although this mutation was not found in the DNA of his skin fibroblasts, it was present in the father's somatic DNA extracted from hair root bulbs and lymphocytes. Furthermore, this mutation was identified in the father's sperm, which indicates that the mutation's presence in different types of the father's cells, including his reproductive cells, is the reason for the condition reappearing in his children. This finding of both reproductive and body cell mosaicism suggests that the mutation occurred before the early developmental division into reproductive and body cell lines. The detection of the mutation in approximately one out of every eight sperm suggests that the human male reproductive line is likely derived from at least four originating cells. The fact that the father, despite being a carrier of the mosaic mutation, appears clinically healthy indicates that genetic disorders can manifest in both the presence or absence of symptoms and in varying degrees of severity.",

original: original_corpus: 'The inadvertent transfer and dispersal of non-indigenous marine species via shipping ballast water is of increasing environmental concern. Despite a major global effort to develop new ballast water treatment technologies, their acceptance has been hampered by the lack of suitable indicator species for assessing treatment effectiveness. Resistant dinoflagellate cysts are one proposed test organism, however their use has been limited due to difficulties in assessing their viability after treatment. The paper describes the development of a rapid method to determine the viability of cysts of the dinoflagellate Alexandrium catenella using staining with SYTOX Green and flow-cytometric analysis. The viability of A. catenella cysts was inversely proportional to their ability to take up the stain. There was excellent agreement between cysts measured as viable/non-viable using flow cytometry and cyst viability determined in standard long-term germination tests. Advantages of the flow-cytometric method include high test precision and rapid testing times of < 2 days, compared to > 4 weeks using existing germination methods.'

original_corpus: 'The goal of this research was to examine the effect of jury deliberations on juror's propensity to disregard inadmissible evidence. Extant research is inconclusive; some research indicates that jurors do follow judicial instructions to ignore inadmissible evidence, but other research suggests that jurors do not. Two experiments examined whether jurors were affected by inadmissible evidence. The results revealed that although mock jurors were biased by inadmissible evidence prior to deliberations, the bias was tempered following deliberations. In Experiment 1, post deliberation jurors disregarded incriminating evidence that was ruled inadmissible because of due-process concerns. Experiment 2 replicated these results with less incriminating inadmissible evidence and also revealed that jurors did not accurately gauge the impact that the inadmissible evidence had on their verdicts. Theoretical and judicial policy implications are discussed.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "The objective of this study was to explore how jury deliberations influence a juror's likelihood to ignore evidence that is not permissible in court. Previous studies have shown mixed results; some suggest that jurors heed judicial directions to overlook such evidence, while others indicate the opposite. This research involved two experiments to determine if jurors were influenced by evidence deemed inadmissible. Findings showed that while mock jurors initially exhibited bias due to inadmissible evidence, this bias diminished after group discussions. In the first experiment, jurors were able to set aside incriminating evidence deemed inadmissible due to concerns over due process, following their deliberations. The second experiment confirmed these findings with evidence that was less incriminating and also highlighted that jurors were not aware of the extent to which the inadmissible evidence affected their decisions. Implications for legal theory and judicial policy were examined.", "named_entities": ["jury deliberations", "inadmissible evidence", "due-process concerns", "judicial instructions"]}

original: original_corpus: 'DNA barcoding was proposed in 2003, the Consortium for the Barcode of Life was established in 2004, and the movement has since attracted more than $80â€ƒmillion funding. Here we investigate how many species of multicellular animals have been barcoded. We compare the numbers in a public database (GenBank as of January 2012) with those in the Barcode of Life Database (BOLD) and find that GenBank contains COI (cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1) sequences for ca. 60â€ƒ000 species while BOLD reports barcodes for ca. 150â€ƒ000 species. The discrepancy is likely due to a large amount of unpublished data in BOLD. Overall, the species coverage remains sparse, growth rates are low, and the barcode accumulation curve for Metazoa is linear with only 4788 species having been added in 2011. In addition, the vast majority of species in the public database (73%) were barcoded by projects that are unlikely to be related to the DNA barcoding movement. Particularly surprising was the large number of DNA barcodes in GenBank that were not identified to species (Jan 2012: 74%), with insect barcodes often being identified only to order. Of these several hundred thousand have since been suppressed by NCBI because they did not satisfy the iBOL/GenBank early release agreement. Species coverage is considerably better for target taxa of DNA barcoding campaigns (e.g. birds, fishes, Lepidoptera), although it also falls short of published campaign targets. Â© The Willi Hennig Society 2012.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "The concept of DNA barcoding was introduced in 2003, leading to the formation of the Consortium for the Barcode of Life in 2004. Since its inception, the initiative has garnered over $80 million in funding. This study explores the extent of multicellular animal species that have undergone DNA barcoding. By analyzing data from GenBank (as of January 2012) and comparing it with the Barcode of Life Database (BOLD), we observed that GenBank lists approximately 60,000 species with COI (cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1) sequences, whereas BOLD documents barcodes for about 150,000 species. This significant difference can be attributed to a vast quantity of data in BOLD that has not been published. Despite these numbers, the overall species coverage by DNA barcoding is rather limited, the growth in the number of barcoded species is slow, and the rate of barcode collection for Metazoa shows a straight line, with only 4,788 species added in the year 2011 alone. Furthermore, a large proportion of species barcoded in the public database (73%) were done through efforts not directly associated with the DNA barcoding initiative. It was also noted that a substantial number of DNA barcodes present in GenBank by January 2012 were not identified at the species level (74%), particularly for insects, which were often classified only by order. Many of these records have been subsequently removed by the NCBI for failing to meet the criteria set by the iBOL/GenBank early release agreement. The coverage for species targeted by DNA barcoding campaigns, such as birds, fishes, and Lepidoptera, is relatively better, yet still does not meet the objectives outlined by these campaigns. original: original_corpus: 'The effect of Saccharomyces boulardii on the immune system was evaluated, comparing germ-free Swiss/NIH mice monoassociated with the probiotic with germ-free mice. Saccharomyces boulardii colonized the gut of germ-free mice and survived the gastrointestinal conditions. An increase in sIgA production, both total and anti-S. boulardii, was observed in the intestinal contents of monoassociated mice when compared with germ-free controls. The number of Kupffer cells was significantly higher in monoassociated mice than in germ-free controls. In S. boulardii-monoassociated mice, clearance of Escherichia coli B41 was higher than in germ-free controls. TNF-alpha, IFN-gamma and IL-12 serum levels were higher at earlier time points in monoassociated mice when compared with germ-free mice. These results show that the yeast S. boulardii modulates the host immune responses. This effect may be of interest for improving the resistance to enteropathogenic bacterial infections.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus":"The impact of Saccharomyces boulardii on immune function was studied by comparing germ-free Swiss/NIH mice that were monoassociated with this probiotic to those without any probiotic association. Saccharomyces boulardii successfully colonized the intestines of germ-free mice and withstood the conditions of the gastrointestinal tract. A notable increase in the production of sIgA, including total and anti-S. boulardii specific antibodies, was detected in the intestinal contents of mice associated with the probiotic versus germ-free counterparts. Additionally, monoassociated mice exhibited a significantly higher count of Kupffer cells compared to their germ-free peers. Furthermore, the elimination of Escherichia coli B41 was more efficient in the mice associated with S. boulardii. Levels of TNF-alpha, IFN-gamma, and IL-12 in the serum were elevated at earlier stages in the monoassociated mice in comparison to the germ-free group. These findings indicate that the yeast S. boulardii has a regulatory effect on the immune responses of the host. This regulatory effect is potentially beneficial for enhancing resistance against infections caused by enteropathogenic bacteria.","named_entities":["Saccharomyces boulardii","sIgA","Kupffer cells","Escherichia coli B41","TNF-alpha","IFN-gamma","IL-12"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Recently, lateral flow assay (LFA) for nucleic acid detection has drawn increasing attention in the point-of-care testing fields. Due to its rapidity, easy implementation, and low equipment requirement, it is well suited for use in rapid diagnosis, food authentication, and environmental monitoring under source-limited conditions. This review will discuss two main research directions of lateral flow nucleic acid tests. The first one is the incorporation of isothermal amplification methods with LFA, which ensures an ultra-high testing sensitivity under non-laboratory conditions. The two most commonly used methodologies will be discussed, namely Loop-mediated Isothermal Amplification (LAMP) and Recombinase Polymerase Amplification (RPA), and some novel methods with special properties will also be introduced. The second research direction is the development of novel labeling materials. It endeavors to increase the sensitivity and quantifiability of LFA testing, where signals can be read and analyzed by portable devices. These methods are compared in terms of limits of detection, detection times, and quantifiabilities. It is anticipated that future research on lateral flow nucleic acid tests will focus on the integration of the whole testing process into a microfluidic system and the combination with molecular diagnostic tools such as clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats to facilitate a rapid and accurate test.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "The use of lateral flow assays (LFAs) for detecting nucleic acids has become increasingly popular in point-of-care testing scenarios. Their speed, simplicity, and minimal equipment needs make them ideal for quick diagnostic purposes, verifying food origins, and environmental checks in settings with limited resources. This article reviews two primary avenues of research within the field of lateral flow nucleic acid testing. The first involves using isothermal amplification techniques alongside LFAs to achieve exceptionally high sensitivity for testing outside of traditional lab environments. The review will cover the two most prevalent methods, Loop-mediated Isothermal Amplification (LAMP) and Recombinase Polymerase Amplification (RPA), in addition to a few emerging techniques with unique capabilities. The second research area focuses on the development of new labeling substances aimed at improving LFA tests' sensitivity and the ability to quantify results. These improvements allow for the digital reading and analysis of results with mobile devices. These advancements are evaluated based on their detection limits, time efficiency, and quantification abilities. Looking ahead, it is expected that future studies will concentrate on merging the entire testing process into a compact microfluidic device and integrating it with molecular diagnostic technologies like clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats, enhancing the speed and precision of diagnostics.", "named_entities": ["lateral flow assay (LFA)", "nucleic acid detection", "Loop-mediated Isothermal Amplification (LAMP)", "Recombinase Polymerase Amplification (RPA)", "microfluidic system", "clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Withania somnifera, popularly known as Indian ginseng, is one of the most important medicinal plants. The plant is well studied in terms of its pharmaceutical activities and genes involved in biosynthetic pathways. However, not much is known about the regulatory mechanism of genes responsible for the production of secondary metabolites. The idea was to identify miRNA transcriptome responsible for the regulation of withanolide biosynthesis, specifically of root and leaf tissues individually. The transcriptome data of in vitro culture of root and leaf tissues of the plant was considered for miRNA identification. A total of 24 and 39 miRNA families were identified in root and leaf tissues, respectively. Out of these, 15 and 27 miRNA families have shown their involvement in different biological functions in root and leaf tissues, respectively. We report here, specific miRNAs and their corresponding target genes for corresponding root and leaf tissues. The target genes have also been analyzed for their role in withanolide metabolism. Endogenous root-miR5140, root-miR159, leaf-miR477, and leaf-miR530 were reported for regulation of withanolide biosynthesis.'

The aim was to uncover the miRNA transcriptome that governs the synthesis of withanolides, focusing on the root and leaf tissues separately. The study utilized transcriptome data from in vitro cultured root and leaf tissues for miRNA detection. In the roots and leaves, 24 and 39 miRNA families were discovered, respectively. Among these, 15 miRNA families in roots and 27 in leaves were found to participate in various biological roles. This research highlights particular miRNAs and their target genes in the roots and leaves, examining their contributions to withanolide metabolism. Notably, root-miR5140, root-miR159, leaf-miR477, and leaf-miR530 have been identified as regulators of withanolide biosynthesis.", "named_entities": ["Withania somnifera", "Indian ginseng", "miRNA", "withanolide biosynthesis", "transcriptome", "root-miR5140", "root-miR159", "leaf-miR477", "leaf-miR530"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Yin-Chen-Hao-Tang (YCHT) is a famous Chinese medicine formula which has long been used in clinical practice for treating various liver diseases, such as liver fibrosis. However, to date, the mechanism for its anti-fibrotic effects remains unclear. In this paper, an ultra-performance liquid chromatography-time-of-flight mass spectrometry (UPLC-TOF-MS)-based metabolomic study was performed to characterize dimethylnitrosamine (DMN)-induced liver fibrosis in rats and evaluate the therapeutic effects of YCHT. Partial least squares-discriminant analysis (PLS-DA) showed that the model group was well separated from the control group, whereas the YCHT-treated group exhibited a tendency to restore to the controls. Seven significantly changed fibrosis-related metabolites, including unsaturated fatty acids and lysophosphatidylcholines (Lyso-PCs), were identified. Moreover, statistical analysis demonstrated that YCHT treatment could reverse the levels of most metabolites close to the normal levels. These results, along with histological and biochemical examinations, indicate that YCHT has anti-fibrotic effects, which may be due to the suppression of oxidative stress and resulting lipid peroxidation involved in hepatic fibrogenesis. This study offers new opportunities to improve our understanding of liver fibrosis and the anti-fibrotic mechanisms of YCHT.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Yin-Chen-Hao-Tang (YCHT), a renowned traditional Chinese herbal blend, has been historically utilized for the treatment of various liver conditions, including liver fibrosis, but its anti-fibrotic mechanisms have remained elusive. In this research, a study utilizing ultra-performance liquid chromatography-time-of-flight mass spectrometry (UPLC-TOF-MS) was conducted to investigate liver fibrosis caused by dimethylnitrosamine (DMN) in rats and to assess the healing effects of YCHT. Through partial least squares-discriminant analysis (PLS-DA), it was observed that the YCHT treatment group started to revert to the state of the control group, distinguishing the model group from the untreated controls. This analysis identified seven fibrosis-associated metabolites that significantly altered, including unsaturated fatty acids and lysophosphatidylcholines (Lyso-PCs). Furthermore, YCHT treatment was found to nearly normalize the levels of these metabolites, according to statistical analysis. Combined with histological and biochemical tests, these findings suggest YCHT's potential in mitigating fibrosis, possibly by inhibiting oxidative stress and the subsequent lipid peroxidation that plays a role in liver fibrogenesis. original: original_corpus: 'Van der Waals (vdW) heterostructures stacked vertically by graphene (Gr) and hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN), by virtue of their novel properties, will undoubtedly spark great interests from the perspective of basic physics and applied science. Herein, phonon thermal transport across multilayer Gr/h-BN vdW heterostructures was systematically investigated by extensive molecular dynamics simulations, both in terms of internal structural configuration and external modulation. The former includes the structural configuration at the Gr/h-BN interface, the proportion of components in the effective heat transfer area, and size effect, while the latter includes cross-plane strain, temperature, and interfacial coupling strength. Our results show that at 300 K it has an ultralow out-of-plane thermal conductivity of only about 8.93 MWm<sup>-1</sup> K<sup>-1</sup>, while the Gr/h-BN interfacial thermal conductance (ITC) is up to about 300 MWm<sup>-2</sup> K<sup>-1</sup>, and the latter can be modulated in a wide range from 0.5 to 3.5 times under cross-plane strain. The analysis of the spectral decomposition results indicates that the thermal transport across the Gr/h-BN interface depends almost entirely on low-frequency out-of-plane phonons below 10 THz and the quantum effect can be ignorable, which uncovers the physical mechanisms underlying the changes in the ITC and also points the path toward its modulation.'

Internal factors include the arrangement at the Gr/h-BN boundary, the ratio of components crucial for heat transfer, and the impact of size. External factors encompass the effects of cross-plane strain, ambient temperature, and the strength of interfacial coupling. The findings reveal that at a temperature of 300 K, the heterostructures exhibit an exceptionally low out-of-plane thermal conductivity, approximately 8.93 MWm-1 K-1, whereas the Gr/h-BN interfacial thermal conductance (ITC) reaches up to about 300 MWm-2 K-1. The ITC can be varied significantly, between 0.5 to 3.5 times, through the application of cross-plane strain. Spectral analysis demonstrates that the heat transport across the Gr/h-BN interface is predominantly governed by low-frequency out-of-plane phonons below 10 THz, with quantum effects being negligible.
