A variety of chiral tagging agents have been devised for different functional groups, including amino groups, carboxyl groups, thiols, and hydroxyl groups. This section outlines the techniques for indirectly determining the chirality of molecules via high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), focusing on the creation of diastereomers. It particularly discusses the use of chiral benzofurazan-based agents, namely, 4-(3-aminopyrrolidin-1-yl)-7-(N,N-dimethylaminosulfonyl)-2,1,3-benzoxadiazole (DBD-APy) and 4-(3-isothiocyanatopyrrolidin-1-yl)-7-(N,N-dimethylaminosulfonyl)-2,1,3-benzoxadiazole (DBD-PyNCS), in detail for the steps of derivatization, separation, and detection.", "named_entities": ["enantiomers", "chiral pharmaceuticals", "amino acids", "HPLC", "diastereomer", "DBD-APy", "DBD-PyNCS"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Demodex folliculorum (Follicular or Demodicid mite) is a zoonotic obligatory parasite with clinical manifestations range from normal infestation to complicated ones. Treatment of human facial demodicidosis with freshly prepared camphor oil with or without glycerol dilutions gave complete cure with concentrations of 100%, 75%. and 50%. Incomplete cure but marked drop in infestation density was achieved with diluted camphor oil at concentrations of 25-20%. Camphor oil application proved to be safe with no side effects.'

original: original_corpus: 'Chymopapain (1 mg) was injected into each of four-lumbar intervertebral discs of adult mongrel dogs. As expected, at 2 weeks, all injected discs exhibited marked loss of height (mean: 50% of original height) indicative of severe proteoglycan depletion. The appearance of keratan sulfate-bearing fragments in plasma was monitored by an ELISA-inhibition assay which uses a monoclonal antibody (1/20/5-D-4) specific for an epitope present only in the longest keratan sulfate chains. Levels of plasma keratan sulfate rose within 30 minutes and reached a maximum between 24 and 72 hours later. Levels then declined progressively but were still elevated at 2 weeks postinjection. Keratan sulfate-bearing fragments in plasma were purified by ion exchange chromatography on DEAE-Sephacryl and fractionated by sieve chromatography on Sepharose CL-6B. These plasma keratan sulfate-bearing fragments were found to be similar in size to keratan sulfate-bearing fragments generated by chymopapain digestion of dog nucleus pulposus proteoglycans, but slightly larger than single keratan sulfate chains obtained by alkaline borohydride treatment of dog nucleus pulposus proteoglycans. The results of this study show that measurements of blood levels of keratan sulfate could prove useful in monitoring effective degradation of disc proteoglycans in chemonucleolysis in man and help discriminate between ineffective enzyme placement, and alternative mechanisms of treatment failure.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Chymopapain, at a dosage of 1 mg, was administered into the lumbar intervertebral discs of adult mongrel dogs, involving four discs in total. Two weeks post-injection, a significant reduction in disc height was observed, averaging a 50% decrease from the original height, signaling extensive loss of proteoglycan. An ELISA-inhibition assay, employing a monoclonal antibody that targets a unique epitope present only in the longest chains of keratan sulfate, was used to track the presence of keratan sulfate fragments in the blood. These keratan sulfate levels in the plasma began to rise within half an hour, peaking sometime between 24 to 72 hours following the injection, before gradually diminishing, yet remained higher than normal two weeks after the injection. The plasma's keratan sulfate fragments underwent purification through ion exchange chromatography using DEAE-Sephacryl and were then fractionated by sieve chromatography on Sepharose CL-6B. These fragments were comparable in size to those produced by chymopapain treatment of dog nucleus pulposus proteoglycans, and were marginally bigger than the individual keratan sulfate chains derived from alkaline borohydride processing of dog nucleus pulposus proteoglycans. original: original_corpus: 'We recently reported that H-Lys psi (CH2NH)Lys-Pro-Tyr-Ile-Leu-OH (JMV 449), a pseudopeptide analogue of neurotensin-(8-13) with a reduced CH2NH bond in position 8-9, was about 3 times more potent than neurotensin in binding to mouse brain membranes and in contracting the guinea-pig ileum, and was markedly more resistant to degradation than neurotensin when exposed to rat brain membranes. In the present study, we compared the time courses and dose-response relationships for the ability of i.c.v. injected neurotensin and JMV 449 to elicit hypothermia and analgesia (tail-flick test) in the mouse. The results show that the pseudopeptide analogue behaved as a highly potent and long-lasting neurotensin agonist in these two in vivo bioassays. The analogue should prove very useful for studying the effects of chronic neurotensin receptor stimulation in vitro and in vivo.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "In our recent publication, we disclosed that H-Lys psi (CH2NH)Lys-Pro-Tyr-Ile-Leu-OH (JMV 449), a pseudopeptide variant of neurotensin-(8-13) featuring a modified CH2NH bond between positions 8 and 9, exhibited approximately threefold greater potency than neurotensin in binding to mouse brain membranes and inducing contractions in the guinea-pig ileum. Additionally, it demonstrated a significantly higher resistance to degradation by rat brain membranes compared to neurotensin. In this study, we evaluated the temporal progression and dose-dependency of neurotensin and JMV 449, administered via intracerebroventricular (i.c.v.) injection, in producing hypothermia and analgesia (assessed by the tail-flick test) in mice. Our findings reveal that the pseudopeptide analogue acted as an exceedingly potent and durable agonist of the neurotensin receptor in these in vivo assays. This analogue is anticipated to be exceedingly valuable in the exploration of sustained neurotensin receptor activation effects both in vitro and in vivo.", "named_entities": ["H-Lys psi (CH2NH)Lys-Pro-Tyr-Ile-Leu-OH", "JMV 449", "neurotensin", "mouse brain membranes", "guinea-pig ileum", "rat brain membranes", "i.c.v.", "hypothermia", "analgesia", "tail-flick test"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) is the most common neuromuscular disorder and is associated with cardiac conduction defects. However, the mechanisms of cardiac arrhythmias in DM1 are unknown. We tested the hypothesis that abnormalities in the cardiac sodium current (INa) are involved, and used a transgenic mouse model reproducing the expression of triplet expansion observed in DM1 (DMSXL mouse). The injection of the class-I antiarrhythmic agent flecainide induced prominent conduction abnormalities and significantly lowered the radial tissular velocities and strain rate in DMSXL mice compared to WT. These abnormalities were more pronounced in 8-month-old mice than in 3-month-old mice. Ventricular action potentials recorded by standard glass microelectrode technique exhibited a lower maximum upstroke velocity [dV/dt](max) in DMSXL. This decreased [dV/dt](max) was associated with a 1.7 fold faster inactivation of INa in DMSXL myocytes measured by the whole-cell patch-clamp technique. Finally in the DMSXL mouse, no mutation in the Scn5a gene was detected and neither cardiac fibrosis nor abnormalities of expression of the sodium channel protein were observed. Therefore, alterations in the sodium current markedly contributed to electrical conduction block in DM1. This result should guide pharmaceutical and clinical research toward better therapy for the cardiac arrhythmias associated with DM1.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1), the most prevalent neuromuscular disease, is linked with heart rhythm abnormalities. The cause of these cardiac arrhythmias in DM1 remains unclear. Our study aimed to investigate if disturbances in the heart's sodium current (INa) play a role, utilizing a transgenic mouse model that mimics the triplet repeat expansion seen in DM1 (DMSXL mouse). Administration of the class-I antiarrhythmic drug flecainide in DMSXL mice led to significant conduction issues and notably reduced radial tissue velocities and strain rates compared to wild-type (WT) mice. These issues were more evident in mice aged 8 months than those aged 3 months. Ventricular action potentials, measured using the traditional glass microelectrode approach, showed a reduced peak upstroke velocity [dV/dt](max) in DMSXL mice. This reduction in [dV/dt](max) corresponded with a 1.7 times quicker inactivation of INa in DMSXL myocytes, as determined by whole-cell patch-clamp measurements. Importantly, no mutations were found in the Scn5a gene of DMSXL mice, and there were no signs of cardiac fibrosis or anomalies in the expression of the sodium channel protein. Thus, changes in the sodium current were significantly implicated in the electrical conduction disturbances seen in DM1, suggesting that future pharmacological and clinical research should focus on developing improved treatments for DM1-associated cardiac arrhythmias.", "named_entities": ["Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1)", "cardiac sodium current (INa)", "DMSXL mouse", "flecainide", "whole-cell patch-clamp technique", "Scn5a gene"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Photoacoustic measurements made at various chopping frequencies on dense acqueous melanin suspensions have revealed a significant dependence upon pH and redox state. It is shown that such behaviour, differing from the simple predictions of the Rosencwaig-Gersho theory, can be explained in terms of finite carrier diffusion and recombination times. The implications of these findings with respect to the amorphous semiconductor model proposed to describe the dynamic role of epidermal melanin are discussed. From the experimental data, values of physical parameters were calculated which allow a qualitative correlation between chemical states and electronic behaviour and, consequently, some aspects of the molecular biology of the melanosome, founded on a rigorous base.'

original_corpus: '(1) A comparative study of the polymorphic phase behaviour of reconstituted erythrocyte phospholipase with 'fusogens' and chemically related 'non-fusogens' using 31P-NMR techniques has been made. We demonstrate that only fusogens can induce a conformational change in the membrane lipids from the bilayer of the hexagonal (HII) phase. (2) The tendency of erythrocyte (ghost) membranes to adopt nonbilayer structures is correlated with the extent of fusion in erythrocytes at various membrane concentrations of glycerol monooleate. Above a certain critical membrane concentration of glycerol monooleate, there is an increase in the tendency of ghost membranes to adopt the HII phase, which is paralleled by a marked increase in fusion processes in the intact erythrocytes. (3) These observations are consistent with a common mechanism of action for fusogenic lipids whereby inverted lipid structures such as long cylinders (HII configuration) or inverted micelles are induced, which serve as intermediates in the fusion event.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "A study compared the polymorphic phase behaviors of erythrocyte phospholipase when reconstituted with 'fusogens' and similar 'non-fusogens,' utilizing 31P-NMR techniques. It was shown that fusogens uniquely prompt a conformational shift in the membrane lipids from a bilayer to a hexagonal (HII) phase. The inclination of erythrocyte (ghost) membranes to form nonbilayer structures was linked with the degree of fusion in erythrocytes at varying glycerol monooleate membrane concentrations. Beyond a specific crucial concentration of glycerol monooleate, ghost membranes more frequently assumed the HII phase, coinciding with a significant rise in fusion activities in whole erythrocytes. These findings suggest a uniform mechanism by which fusogenic lipids cause the formation of inverted lipid structures, such as long cylinders (HII configuration) or inverted micelles, acting as intermediates in the fusion process.", "named_entities": ["erythrocyte phospholipase", "fusogens", "31P-NMR", "HII phase", "glycerol monooleate", "fusion processes", "inverted micelles"]}

original: original_corpus: 'We studied the time course of serum IgG antibodies against 3 different pertussis vaccine antigens: PT (pertussis toxin), FHA (filamentous hemagglutinin), Prn (pertactin) in sera from individuals vaccinated with four different pertussis vaccines at 4 years of age: (N=44, 44, 23 and 23, respectively,) and compared the responses to/after natural infection with Bordetella pertussis (N=44, age 1-8 years). These longitudinal data were analyzed with a novel method, using a mathematical model to describe the observed responses, and their variation among subjects. This allowed us to estimate biologically meaningful characteristics of the serum antibody response, like peak level and decay rate, and to compare these among natural infections and vaccine responses. Compared to natural infection, responses to PT after vaccination with the tested vaccines are smaller in magnitude and tend to decay slightly faster. When present in vaccines, FHA and Prn tend to produce high peak levels, higher than those in naturally infected patients, but these decay faster. As expected, the Dutch whole cell vaccine produced lower antibody responses than the acellular vaccines. This model allows a better comparison of the kinetics of vaccine induced antibody responses and after natural infection over a long follow up period.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Our research focused on examining the progression of serum IgG antibodies against three specific antigens of the pertussis vaccine: PT (pertussis toxin), FHA (filamentous hemaglutinin), and Prn (pertactin) in individuals who were vaccinated with four different pertussis vaccines at the age of 4 (with group sizes of 44, 44, 23, and 23, respectively). We also assessed how these responses compared to those following a natural infection with Bordetella pertussis in a cohort of 44 individuals between the ages of 1 to 8 years. To analyze these longitudinal data, we employed an innovative approach using a mathematical model, which helped in quantifying the observed antibody responses and their variability across individuals. This model provided us with the ability to quantitatively determine important characteristics of the antibody response, such as the peak levels and the rate of decline, and to contrast these characteristics between natural infections and responses elicited by vaccination. Our findings suggest that, compared to natural infection, the vaccine-induced responses to PT are of a smaller magnitude and decay at a slightly quicker pace. Vaccines containing FHA and Prn were noted to elicit peak antibody levels that surpassed those in naturally infected individuals, although these levels diminished more quickly. As anticipated, the Dutch whole cell vaccine elicited weaker antibody responses than the acellular vaccines. By using this model, we were able to more accurately compare the dynamics of antibody responses induced by vaccines and those following natural infection over an extended period of observation.", "named_entities": ["IgG antibodies", "pertussis vaccine", "PT (pertussis toxin)", "FHA (filamentous hemagglutinin)", "Prn (pertactin)", "Bordetella pertussis", "Dutch whole cell vaccine", "acellular vaccines"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Most thiopeptide antibiotics target the translational machinery: thiostrepton (ThS) and nosiheptide (NoS) target the ribosome and inhibit translation factor function, whereas GE2270A/T binds to the elongation factor EF-Tu and prevents ternary complex formation. We have used several in vitro translational machinery assays to screen a library of thiopeptide antibiotic precursor compounds and identified four families of precursor compounds that are either themselves inhibitory or are able to relieve the inhibitory effects of ThS, NoS, or GE2270T. Some of these precursors represent distinct compounds with respect to their ability to bind to ribosomes. The results not only provide insight into the mechanism of action of thiopeptide compounds but also demonstrate the potential of such assays for identifying lead compounds that might be missed using conventional inhibitory screening protocols.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "A majority of thiopeptide antibiotics are known to act on the protein synthesis machinery: thiostrepton (ThS) and nosiheptide (NoS) interfere with ribosomal function and block translation factor activity, while GE2270A/T attaches to the elongation factor EF-Tu, blocking the formation of the ternary complex. Through various in vitro assays focused on the translational apparatus, we evaluated a collection of thiopeptide antibiotic precursor molecules and discovered four distinct classes of precursor compounds. These compounds either exhibit inhibitory properties on their own or can counteract the inhibitory effects of ThS, NoS, or GE2270T. Some of these precursor molecules are unique in their interaction with ribosomes. These findings not only shed light on how thiopeptide agents work but also highlight the effectiveness of such assays in pinpointing promising lead compounds that might be overlooked with traditional inhibitory screening methods.", "named_entities": ["thiostrepton", "nosiheptide", "GE2270A/T", "EF-Tu", "ribosome", "translational machinery", "thiopeptide antibiotic precursor compounds"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is increasingly recognized in critically ill immunocompetent patients. Some studies have demonstrated an association between CMV disease and increased mortality rates, prolonged intensive care unit and hospital length of stay, prolonged mechanical ventilation, and nosocomial infections. However, there is a considerable controversy whether such association represents a causal relationship between CMV disease and unfavorable outcomes or just a marker of the severity of the critical illness. Detection of CMV using polymerase chain reaction and CMV antigenemia is the standard diagnostic approach. CMV may have variety of clinical manifestations reflecting the involvement of different organ systems. Treatment of CMV in critical care is challenging due to diagnostic challenge and drug toxicity, and building predictive model for CMV disease in critical care setting would be promising to identify patients at risk and starting prophylactic therapy. Our objective was to broadly review the current literature on the prevalence and incidence, clinical manifestations, potential limitations of different diagnostic modalities, prognosis, and therapeutic options of CMV disease in critically ill patients.'

original_corpus: 'Evolutionary emergence of agents in the empirical world is a direct consequence of the indexicality of matter itself. It is grounded upon the act of quantum origin that is accessible indexically with use of our language. One unique aspect of our language rests upon its appraisal of different grammatical tenses, such as the present progressive tense and the perfect one. Both the tenses are indexical in pointing to some movements in progress or registered in stasis as such out there as admitting no anthropocentric interventions. In particular, the material movement mediated by the transfer of the quantum particles is punctuated by the event of the transfer completed so far that can be referred to in the present perfect tense. At the same time, the transfer of the quantum particles can constantly induce the similar transfer in sequence in the following present progressive tense. Constant update of the present perfect tense in the subsequent progressive tense is agential in keeping no inconsistency between the two left behind in the finished record. That is the inconsistency-mediating cohesion acting between the present perfect and the progressive tenses. A most conspicuous case demonstrating the competency of inconsistency-mediating cohesion may be the origins of life. Molecular recognition widely observed in the biological realm is a specific instance of demonstrating such a molecular cohesion.'

original_corpus: 'Standard algorithms for pairwise protein sequence alignment make the simplifying assumption that amino acid substitutions at neighboring sites are uncorrelated. This assumption allows implementation of fast algorithms for pairwise sequence alignment, but it ignores information that could conceivably increase the power of remote homolog detection. We examine the validity of this assumption by constructing extended substitution matrices that encapsulate the observed correlations between neighboring sites, by developing an efficient and rigorous algorithm for pairwise protein sequence alignment that incorporates these local substitution correlations and by assessing the ability of this algorithm to detect remote homologies.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Common methods for aligning pairs of protein sequences typically operate under the premise that changes in amino acids at adjacent sites do not influence each other. This premise supports the development of rapid algorithms for aligning two sequences at a time, yet it overlooks potentially valuable data that might enhance the identification of distantly related proteins. Our study tests the accuracy of this assumption by creating comprehensive substitution matrices that include the noted interconnections between adjacent sites. We also introduce a precise and effective method for aligning protein sequences that takes into account these correlations of substitutions at local sites, and we evaluate how well this method can identify proteins that are remotely related.", "named_entities": ["pairwise protein sequence alignment", "amino acid substitutions", "substitution matrices", "local substitution correlations", "remote homologies"]}

original: original_corpus: 'The memory resistor with the moniker memristor was a harmless postulate in 1971. Since 2008 a device that claims to be the memristor is on the prowl, seeking recognition as a fundamental circuit element, sometimes wanting electronics textbooks to be rewritten, always promising remarkable digital, analog and neuromorphic computing possibilities. A systematic discussion about the fundamental nature of the device is almost absent within the memristor community. Advocates use incomplete constitutive relationships, ignore concepts of activity/passivity and aver that nonlinearity is central to their case. Few researchers have examined these claims. Our report investigates the assertion that the memristor is a fundamental passive circuit element, from the fresh perspective that electrical engineering is the science of charge management. We demonstrate with a periodic table of fundamental elements that the 2008 memristor is not the 1971 postulate and neither of them is fundamental. The ideal memristor is an unphysical active device and any physically realizable memristor is a nonlinear composition of resistors with active hysteresis. We also show that there exists only three fundamental passive circuit elements.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "In 1971, the concept of a memory resistor, known as a memristor, was merely theoretical. By 2008, a device claiming to be this memristor emerged, actively seeking validation as an essential circuit component, even suggesting the need for rewriting electronics textbooks and boasting of its potential to revolutionize digital, analog, and neuromorphic computing. However, within the community surrounding the memristor, there is hardly any comprehensive debate on the device's fundamental nature. Proponents often rely on incomplete constitutive relationships, overlook the principles of activity/passivity, and insist on the importance of nonlinearity to their argument. Only a handful of researchers have scrutinized these assertions. Our analysis challenges the claim that the memristor is a fundamental passive circuit element, approaching the subject with the novel idea that electrical engineering essentially involves managing charge. Our findings, presented through a periodic table of fundamental elements, reveal that the memristor introduced in 2008 does not align with the original 1971 hypothesis, and neither qualifies as fundamental. We argue that an ideal memristor would behave as an unphysical, active device, and any memristor that can be physically realized is merely a nonlinear combination of resistors featuring active hysteresis. Our study concludes that there are only three fundamental passive circuit elements.", "named_entities": ["memristor", "1971", "2008", "neuromorphic computing", "active hysteresis", "passive circuit element"]}

original: original_corpus: 'A homogeneous sample of lipoxygenase from rabbit reticulocyte cytosol was obtained. The rate of exogenous arachidonate oxidation by reticulocyte lipoxygenase was found to increase in the presence of various blood plasma lipoproteins of mammals. The rate of arachidonate oxidation by soybean lipoxygenase in the presence of these lipoproteins was either unaffected or decreased. The lipoproteins immobilized the substrate; however, preliminary "saturation" of the lipoproteins by a manyfold excess of non-oxidizable oleate did not eliminate the enzyme activation by the lipoproteins. It was concluded that lipoxygenase activation is due to conformational changes of the enzyme during its interaction with membrane components.'

original_corpus: 'Although Alzheimer's disease has long been considered mainly a cognitive disorder, behavioral and psychological symptoms are present from its onset and at all the stages of the disease in most patients. They must be identified from the beginning because they orient the diagnosis. They include affective and emotional disorders, delusions and hallucinations, disorders of instinctual behavior and behavioral problems. The best tool for assessing them is the Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI). They are generally related to neurobiological aspects of the disease but may, especially when acute, have multiple etiologies: somatic, iatrogenic, psychological and environmental. They condition the course of the disease. As a source of suffering and reduced quality of the life and as the primary cause of distress for the caregivers and hence of hospitalization and institutionalization, they increase the costs of care. The challenge today is to learn more about them and thus improve their treatment and especially their prevention.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Alzheimer's disease, traditionally viewed primarily as a cognitive disorder, exhibits behavioral and psychological symptoms from its early stages throughout the disease progression in the majority of patients. Recognizing these symptoms early is crucial as they guide the diagnostic process. Symptoms encompass mood and emotional disturbances, delusions, hallucinations, instinctual and behavioral abnormalities. The Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) serves as the optimal instrument for their evaluation. These symptoms are often linked to the neurobiological changes brought about by Alzheimer's disease, but can also arise from a variety of causes including physical health issues, medication side effects, psychological factors, and environmental influences. They play a significant role in determining the disease's trajectory. Besides causing suffering and diminishing the quality of life for the patients, these symptoms are a major source of stress for caregivers, leading to increased hospitalizations and the need for institutional care, thereby raising healthcare expenses. The current imperative is to deepen our understanding of these symptoms to enhance their management and, most importantly, to focus on preventive measures.", "named_entities": ["Alzheimer's disease", "Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI)", "neurobiological"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Tumor-suppressive miR-34a, a direct target of p53, has been shown to target several molecules of cell survival pathways. Here, we show that capsaicin-induced oxidative DNA damage culminates in p53 activation to up-regulate expression of miR-34a in non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC) cells. Functional analyses further indicate that restoration of miR-34a inhibits B cell lymphoma-2 (Bcl-2) protein expression to withdraw the survival advantage of these resistant NSCLC cells. In such a proapoptotic cellular milieu, where drug resistance proteins are also down-regulated, p53-transactivated Bcl-2 associated X protein (Bax) induces apoptosis via the mitochondrial death cascade. Our results suggest that p53/miR-34a regulatory axis might be critical in sensitizing drug-resistant NSCLC cells.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "The tumor-inhibiting microRNA miR-34a, which is directly activated by p53, is known to affect several cell survival pathways. We demonstrate that damage to DNA caused by oxidative stress from capsaicin leads to the activation of p53, which then enhances the production of miR-34a in non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC) cells. Our functional studies show that increasing levels of miR-34a can suppress the expression of the B cell lymphoma-2 (Bcl-2) protein, undermining the survival mechanisms of these otherwise resistant NSCLC cells. In this environment conducive to cell death, where proteins associated with drug resistance are diminished, the activation of Bcl-2 associated X protein (Bax) by p53 triggers cell death through the mitochondrial pathway. Our findings indicate that the p53/miR-34a regulatory pathway could play a pivotal role in making drug-resistant NSCLC cells more susceptible to treatment.", "named_entities": ["miR-34a", "p53", "non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC)", "B cell lymphoma-2 (Bcl-2)", "Bcl-2 associated X protein (Bax)"]}

original: original_corpus: 'We investigated the anti-inflammatory activities of argirein and rhein on inflammatory edema in rat paw which was caused by complete adjuvant, compared with ibuprofen. We hypothesized that the adjuvant-induced inflammation is attributed to upregulation of activating transcript factor 6 (ATF6; a chaperone for endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress), p66Shc (an adaptive protein modulating oxidative stress), and NADPH oxidase subunits p22phox and gp91phox in the inflamed tissues. Biomarkers were measured in the rat paw in association with monitoring swellings. The primary inflammatory edema of the injected paw occurred rapidly and sustained over a couple of days, and the secondary inflammation developed 2Â weeks later. The inflammatory edema was accompanied by upregulation of cytokines including ATF6, p66Shc, p22phox, gp91phox, and MMP-2 and an increase in ratio of p-Akt/Akt in the afflicted paw. These were suppressed by either argirein and rhein or ibuprofen. These findings indicate that ER stress, upregulated p66Shc, and phosphorylated Akt are actively implicated in the inflammatory zone caused by adjuvant injection. These biomarkers were causal factors responsible for inflammation of the afflicted paw and were suppressed by a supermolecule argirein and rhein, and the anti-inflammatory activities of the two compounds were comparable to that of ibuprofen.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Our research examined the effects of argirein and rhein on rat paw inflammatory edema, which was triggered by complete adjuvant, and compared these effects with those of ibuprofen. We proposed that the inflammation caused by the adjuvant is due to an increase in the expression of activating transcript factor 6 (ATF6; a molecular chaperone involved in endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress), p66Shc (a protein that adjusts oxidative stress), and components of NADPH oxidase, namely p22phox and gp91phox, within the inflamed tissue. We measured several biomarkers in association with the swelling in the rat paw. The initial inflammation in the injected paw appeared quickly and lasted for a few days, while a secondary phase of inflammation emerged two weeks later. The presence of inflammatory edema correlated with elevated levels of cytokines like ATF6, p66Shc, p22phox, gp91phox, and MMP-2, and a higher p-Akt/Akt ratio in the affected paw. Both argirein and rhein, as well as ibuprofen, were effective in reducing these markers. This suggests that ER stress, increased p66Shc, and activated Akt play significant roles in the inflammation resulting from the adjuvant injection. The biomarkers that contributed to the inflammation were decreased by the actions of the uniquely effective molecules argirein and rhein, whose anti-inflammatory effects were found to be on par with ibuprofen.", "named_entities": ["argirein", "rhein", "inflammatory edema", "ATF6", "p66Shc", "NADPH oxidase", "p22phox", "gp91phox", "ibuprofen"]}

original: original_corpus: 'The differential weed-competitive abilities of eight rice genotypes and the traits that may confer such attributes were investigated under partial weedy and weed-free conditions in naturally occurring weed flora in dry direct-seeded rice during the rainy seasons of 2011 and 2012 at Ludhiana, Punjab, India. The results showed genotypic differences in competitiveness against weeds. In weed-free plots, grain yield varied from 6.6 to 8.9 t ha(-1) across different genotypes; it was lowest for PR-115 and highest for the hybrid H-97158. In partial weedy plots, grain yield and weed biomass at flowering varied from 3.6 to 6.7 t ha(-1) and from 174 to 419 g m(-2), respectively. In partial weedy plots, grain yield was lowest for PR-115 and highest for PR-120. Average yield loss due to weed competition ranged from 21 to 46% in different rice genotypes. The study showed that early canopy closure, high leaf area index at early stage, and high root biomass and volume correlated positively with competitiveness. This study suggests that some traits (root biomass, leaf area index, and shoot biomass at the early stage) could play an important role in conferring weed competitiveness and these traits can be explored for dry-seeded rice.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "The study explored the varying abilities of eight rice genotypes to compete with weeds, along with the characteristics that might enable these capabilities, under both partially weedy and weed-free scenarios amidst the natural weed populations in dry direct-seeded rice during the rainy seasons of 2011 and 2012 in Ludhiana, Punjab, India. The findings revealed genetic variances in weed competition. Under weed-free conditions, the grain yield ranged from 6.6 to 8.9 tons per hectare among the genotypes, with the lowest yield observed in PR-115 and the highest in the hybrid H-97158. In conditions with partial weed presence, the grain yield and weed biomass at the flowering stage varied from 3.6 to 6.7 tons per hectare and 174 to 419 grams per square meter, respectively, with PR-115 showing the lowest grain yield and PR-120 the highest. The average yield reduction due to weed interference was noted to be between 21 to 46% across the different rice genotypes. The research indicated that traits such as early canopy closure, a high leaf area index in the initial stages, and greater root biomass and volume were positively associated with weed competitiveness. original: original_corpus: 'Thirty hypertriglyceridemic patients were treated under metabolic ward conditions for 10 days with either placebo, clofibrate (500 mg t.i.d.) or bezafibrate (200 mg t.i.d.) in a randomized, double-blind study. In addition, patients received an isocaloric prudent diet. On day 10 a diurnal lipid and lipoprotein profile was carried out. Compliance to medication was good. Each treatment led to significant reductions of fasting triglycerides and cholesterol. Lowering of fasting and integrated diurnal triglycerides was greatest with bezafibrate. HDL-cholesterol profiles were highest with this drug. A strong correlation between fasting and diurnal triglycerides was observed. Triglyceride-lowering therapy must therefore aim at fasting triglyceride values as low as possible.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Thirty individuals with high triglyceride levels were treated in a metabolic ward for 10 days using either a placebo, 500 mg of clofibrate thrice daily, or 200 mg of bezafibrate thrice daily, in a study that was both randomized and double-blinded. They also followed a diet with controlled calories designed to be prudent. On the 10th day, a full day's profile of lipid and lipoprotein levels was performed. Adherence to the prescribed medication was high. Each treatment resulted in a notable decrease in both fasting triglycerides and cholesterol levels. The reduction in both fasting and throughout-the-day triglyceride levels was most significant when using bezafibrate, which also led to the highest HDL-cholesterol levels. A strong link was found between fasting triglyceride levels and their daily fluctuations, indicating that therapies aimed at reducing triglycerides should target as low a fasting level as possible.", "named_entities": ["hypertriglyceridemic", "metabolic ward", "placebo", "clofibrate", "bezafibrate", "isocaloric prudent diet", "HDL-cholesterol", "fasting triglycerides"]}

original: original_corpus: 'The goal of this study was to describe seroreversion (SR) in a cohort of human immunodeficiency virus-exposed but uninfected infants. Groups of patients who seroreverted very early or late were examined for salient clinical and immunologic characteristics of the mother or infant. The mean time (+/- s.d.) to seroreversion by enzyme-linked immunoabsorbent assay (ELISA) was 50.1 +/- 14.8 weeks, or 11.6 months (n = 84); the range of times to antibody loss by ELISA was 17.9 to 82.0 weeks. The mean time to seroreversion by Western blot was 68.3 +/- 12.6 weeks, or 15.8 months (n = 51), with a range of 44.9 to 94.1 weeks. Initial anti-human immunodeficiency virus titer as measured by cord blood ELISA optical density (OD) was found to relate significantly to mean time to seroreversion. No relationship to time to seroreversion was demonstrated for gestational age, maternal or neonatal serum immunoglobulin concentrations, maternal CD4 cell counts, maternal alcohol consumption, infantile diarrhea or failure to thrive. The lengthy time to seroreversion seen here demonstrates the 1994 revised Centers for Disease Control and Prevention definition of human immunodeficiency virus infection (based on seropositivity by both ELISA and confirmatory tests persisting beyond 18 months of age) to be accurate in our population. We recommend Western blot testing be used as confirmation for positive ELISAs only after 18 months of age.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "This research aimed to explore the phenomenon of seroreversion (SR) in human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-exposed but uninfected infants, focusing on those who experienced seroreversion either very early or late. The study analyzed key mother or infant clinical and immunological features. On average, seroreversion took place at 50.1 +/- 14.8 weeks, equivalent to 11.6 months (n = 84), when measured using the enzyme-linked immunoabsorbent assay (ELISA) method, with seroreversion times ranging from 17.9 to 82.0 weeks. When using the Western blot method, the average time extended to 68.3 +/- 12.6 weeks, or about 15.8 months (n = 51), with times spanning from 44.9 to 94.1 weeks. A significant correlation was identified between the initial anti-HIV titer, as indicated by the optical density (OD) in cord blood ELISA, and the average time until seroreversion occurred. However, factors such as gestational age, the concentrations of immunoglobulins in maternal or neonatal serum, counts of maternal CD4 cells, maternal alcohol intake, episodes of infantile diarrhea, or failure to thrive in infants showed no significant association with the timing of seroreversion. The extended duration observed for seroreversion in this study validates the accuracy of the 1994 revised definition of HIV infection by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is based on the persistence of seropositivity as confirmed by both ELISA and additional confirmatory tests beyond 18 months of age. It is advised that Western blot testing be applied as a confirmatory test for positive ELISA results only after the child reaches 18 months of age.", "named_entities": ["seroreversion", "human immunodeficiency virus", "enzyme-linked immunoabsorbent assay", "ELISA", "Western blot", "Centers for Disease Control and Prevention"]}

original: original_corpus: 'In this study, we examined the effect of genistein on the severity of dermatitis and level of serum IgE in NC/Nga (NC) mice. NC mice housed in conventional conditions develop spontaneous atopic-like dermatitis; however, oral administration of 20 mg/kg genistein suppresses the development of dermatitis. We also investigated the levels of serum IgE in genistein-treated NC mice and found that the levels were the same as those in control NC mice. We further investigated in vitro IFN-gamma and IL-4 production from spleen cells upon stimulation with anti-CD3 and anti-CD28 mAbs. IFN-gamma production level in NC mice that received 20 mg/kg genistein was significantly lower than that in control NC mice. In contrast, the production level of IL-4 in genistein-treated mice was not significantly different from that in control mice but tended to increase in a dose-dependent manner.'

original_corpus: 'Morpholine, a six-membered heterocycle containing one nitrogen and one oxygen atom, is a moiety of great significance. It forms an important intermediate in many industrial and organic syntheses. Morpholine containing drugs are of high therapeutic value. Its wide array of pharmacological activity includes anti-diabetic, anti-emetic, growth stimulant, anti-depressant, bronchodilator and anticancer. Multi-drug resistance in cancer cases have emerged in the last few years and have led to the failure of many chemotherapeutic drugs. Newer treatment methods and drugs are being developed to overcome this problem. Target based drug discovery is an effective method to develop novel anticancer drugs. To develop newer drugs, previously reported work needs to be studied. Keeping this in mind, last five year's literature on morpholine used as anticancer agents has been reviewed and summarized in the paper herein.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Morpholine, a ring structure with six members that includes one nitrogen and one oxygen atom, plays a crucial role across various fields. It serves as a vital precursor in numerous industrial and organic chemical processes. Drugs that incorporate morpholine are highly valued for their therapeutic properties. The diverse pharmacological effects of these compounds span across treatments for diabetes, nausea, growth promotion, depression, asthma, and cancer. Recently, the rise of multi-drug resistance in cancer has rendered many chemotherapy treatments ineffective. There is ongoing work to develop new treatments and medications to counteract this challenge. Focusing on target-based drug design has proven to be a promising strategy for creating new anticancer medications. To aid in the development of innovative drugs, it's essential to review and analyze the research from the past five years on the use of morpholine as an anticancer agent, which is detailed in the current document.", "named_entities": ["Morpholine", "anti-diabetic", "anti-emetic", "growth stimulant", "anti-depressant", "bronchodilator", "anticancer", "multi-drug resistance", "chemotherapeutic drugs", "target based drug discovery"]}

original: original_corpus: 'A shared enthusiasm towards the highly promising utility of stem cell research brought together clinicians and scientists from academic institutions, government, and industry at the Second Annual International Stem Cells and Regenerative Medicine meeting presented by GeneExpression Systems, Inc. earlier this year. A common theme was echoed by presenters that a deeper understanding of natural development of the whole organism and individual organ systems is needed. Armed with this greater knowledge, a more efficient and conscientious translation of stem cell research may be achieved. Guest lectures included presentations by Dr. Elizabeth H. Blackburn, Dr. Irving L. Weissman, and Dr. Erin Lavik. Attendees were updated and encouraged by these and several other speakers on such topics as stem cell biology, epigenetics, biotechnology, regenerative medicine, tissue engineering, and bioethics. Biomedical engineers and scientists are making steady strides in designing specific three dimensional scaffolds, tracking and controlling stem cells. The future of stem cell research continues to be promising with applications for treating cardiac and neurodegenerative diseases, hearing loss, diabetes, and so on.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "The Second Annual International Stem Cells and Regenerative Medicine meeting, hosted by GeneExpression Systems, Inc. earlier this year, convened clinicians, scientists from academia, government bodies, and the private sector, all united by their optimistic outlook on the potential of stem cell research. The consensus among the speakers was the necessity for a deeper comprehension of the natural development processes of both whole organisms and specific organ systems. Such enhanced understanding is essential for the effective and responsible application of stem cell research findings. Noteworthy presentations were given by Dr. Elizabeth H. Blackburn, Dr. Irving L. Weissman, and Dr. Erin Lavik, among others. These talks, covering a range of subjects including stem cell biology, epigenetics, biotechnology, regenerative medicine, tissue engineering, and bioethics, served to inform and inspire the attendees. Biomedical engineers and scientists are advancing in the creation of tailored three-dimensional scaffolds and in techniques for the monitoring and manipulation of stem cells. Looking forward, the realm of stem cell research holds great promise, with potential treatments for cardiac and neurodegenerative conditions, hearing loss, diabetes, and more on the horizon.", "named_entities": ["GeneExpression Systems, Inc.", "Dr. Elizabeth H. Blackburn", "Dr. Irving L. Weissman", "Dr. Erin Lavik", "stem cell research", "epigenetics", "regenerative medicine", "tissue engineering", "bioethics"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Recent controlled trials, epidemiological analyses and basic research studies offer a comprehensive view of the short and long-term clinical repercussion of de novo acute kidney injury or AKI. While most post-AKI patients recover their baseline renal function, a significant number, approximately ~20% of those affected, will go on to develop long term illness characterized by an increase in late stage CKD, cardiovascular complications, and increased death rates. When AKI occurs in hospitalized patients, selected demographic and laboratory results can be incorporated into risk calculators that identify those at higher risk for long-term complications. This review touches on some of the salient epidemiological studies of the AKI to CKD transition. It also focuses on certain recent advancements in our understanding of the biological and functional impact of AKI on the renal tubule repair mechanism, as well as the important role that genetic, epigenetic, biochemical and inflammatory events, seemingly beneficial to the re-establishment of normal renal function, can be offset by mediators of progressive fibrosis and irreversible structural changes. Characterization of basic processes that mediate the AKI to CKD transition reveals promising pharmacological and biological agents that hopefully will one day be used in the early stages of AKI to prevent its deadly consequences.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Recent studies, including controlled trials, epidemiological research, and foundational scientific inquiries, provide an extensive overview of the immediate and prolonged clinical impacts of acute kidney injury (AKI) that develops for the first time. While the majority of individuals recovering from AKI regain their initial kidney function, about 20% experience a progression to chronic conditions marked by an escalation in late-stage chronic kidney disease (CKD), heart-related issues, and higher mortality rates. In the case of AKI in hospitalized individuals, incorporating specific patient demographics and test results into risk assessment tools helps pinpoint those at an elevated risk for enduring complications. This overview highlights key epidemiological research on the progression from AKI to CKD. Moreover, it delves into the latest insights regarding the biological consequences of AKI on the process of renal tubule repair and underscores the critical role of genetic, epigenetic, biochemical, and inflammatory factors. These factors, initially aiding in kidney function recovery, might be counteracted by agents that drive fibrosis and permanent structural damage. Understanding the fundamental mechanisms facilitating the AKI to CKD transition uncovers potential therapeutic and biological treatments that, it is hoped, could be applied in the early phases of AKI to avert its fatal outcomes.", "named_entities": ["acute kidney injury", "AKI", "CKD", "chronic kidney disease", "renal tubule repair", "epigenetic", "fibrosis"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Critical periods for experience-dependent plasticity are ubiquitous. The idea that experience-dependent plasticity is closely linked with the development of sensory function is still widely held; however, there also is growing evidence for plasticity in the adult nervous system. This article reviews the notion of a critical period for the treatment of amblyopia in light of recent experimental and clinical evidence for neural plasticity. Specifically, adults with amblyopia can improve their perceptual performance via extensive practice on a challenging visual task, and this improvement may transfer to improved visual acuity. Amblyopes achieve this improvement via the mechanisms that have been shown to explain perceptual learning in the normal visual system. It is hypothesized that these same mechanisms account for at least some of the improvement that occurs in the treatment of amblyopia.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "The concept that critical periods exist for the development of experience-driven changes in the brain is well-established. While the connection between such plasticity and the maturation of sensory abilities has long been accepted, recent findings also highlight the capacity for change within the adult nervous system. This article examines the idea of a critical period for amblyopia treatment in view of new experimental and clinical data on neural adaptability. Specifically, it has been found that adults suffering from amblyopia can enhance their perceptual skills through extensive practice on difficult visual tasks, potentially leading to better visual sharpness. Individuals with amblyopia can achieve these enhancements through mechanisms that are also responsible for perceptual learning in a typically functioning visual system. It is suggested that these mechanisms may explain some of the progress seen in treating amblyopia.", "named_entities": ["amblyopia", "neural plasticity", "visual acuity", "perceptual learning"]}

original: original_corpus: 'The amount of casein found in the milk of the tammar wallaby increases as lactation progresses. The increase is due to increasing amounts of beta-casein; the alpha-casein remains largely constant. The alpha-casein is the more highly phosphorylated; the most abundant form is the 10-P, throughout lactation. The level of phosphorylation of beta-casein shifts to lower average values in late lactation, possibly indicating the enzymatic reaction is overloaded by the increasing amounts of beta-casein. Unlike bovine casein micelles, the wallaby micelles are not completely disrupted at pH 7.0 by sequestration of their calcium content with ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA). Complete disruption only follows the addition of sodium dodecyl sulphate, indicating considerably greater importance for hydrophobic bonds in maintaining their integrity. This micellar behaviour indicates that, despite the evolutionary divergence of marsupials millennia ago, the caseins of wallaby milk assemble into micelles in much the same fashion as in bovine milk.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "In the tammar wallaby, the concentration of casein in its milk increases over the course of lactation, mainly due to the rise in beta-casein levels while alpha-casein levels remain relatively unchanged. Alpha-casein is identified as more extensively phosphorylated, with the 10-P form being predominately present throughout the entire lactation period. As lactation advances, the phosphorylation level of beta-casein tends to decrease on average, suggesting that the enzymatic process may be overwhelmed by the growing quantities of beta-casein. Distinct from the casein micelles found in cow's milk, those in wallaby milk do not disintegrate at a neutral pH of 7.0 through the calcium-binding action of ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA). Only the introduction of sodium dodecyl sulphate leads to their complete disintegration, highlighting the significant role of hydrophobic interactions in maintaining their structure. The formation of micelles from wallaby milk caseins, despite the long evolutionary separation between marsupials and other mammals, happens in a comparable manner to that observed in the caseins of bovine milk.", "named_entities": ["casein", "tammar wallaby", "beta-casein", "alpha-casein", "phosphorylated", "ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA)", "sodium dodecyl sulphate"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Osteoporosis frequently coexists with other chronic diseases and syndromes of aging, and therefore multimorbidity interactions can potentially complicate its evaluation and treatment. This article reviews osteoporosis comorbidity interactions with select common diseases of aging including cardiovascular, neurologic, and geriatric syndromes, and select commonly used medications by older adults. Using depression as a case example, we describe the complex relationship between osteoporosis, mood, and antidepressant medications, and the implications of these interactions for patients and clinicians.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Osteoporosis often occurs alongside other long-lasting diseases and aging-related syndromes, making its assessment and management more complex due to interactions with multiple morbidities. This review discusses how osteoporosis interplays with certain prevalent aging diseases such as those affecting the cardiovascular system, neurological conditions, and syndromes observed in geriatric populations, as well as with medications frequently taken by the elderly. Taking depression as a specific instance, the intricate connections between osteoporosis, emotional well-being, and the use of antidepressants are examined. The consequences of these relationships for both patients and healthcare providers are highlighted.", "named_entities": ["Osteoporosis", "cardiovascular", "neurologic", "geriatric syndromes", "antidepressant medications"]}

original: original_corpus: 'The Sixth Eilat Conference on New Antiepileptic Drugs (AEDs) took place in Taormina, Sicily, Italy from 7th to 11th April, 2002. Basic scientists, clinical pharmacologists and neurologists from 27 countries attended the conference, whose main themes included dose-response relationships with conventional and recent AEDs, teratogenic effects of conventional and recent AEDs, update on clinical implications of AED metabolism, prevention of epileptogesis, and seizure aggravation by AEDs. According to tradition, the central part of the conference was devoted to a review of AEDs in development, as well to updates on AEDs, which have been marketed in recent years. This article summarizes the information presented on drugs in preclinical and clinical development, including carabersat (SB-204269), CGX-1007 (Conantokin-G), pregabalin, retigabine (D-23129), safinamide, SPD421 (DP-VPA), SPM 927, talampanel and valrocemide (TV 1901). Updates on fosphenytoin, gabapentin, lamotrigine, levetiracetam, oxcarbazepine, tiagabine, topiramate, vigabatrin, zonisamide, new formulations of valproic acid, and the antiepileptic vagal stimulator device are also presented.'

original_corpus: 'This study investigated the development of children's ability to find the optimal balance between flexibility and stability as a function of the frequency of required task switches. This question was addressed in two situations contrasting the dynamics of engagement of reconfiguration processes (reactive vs. proactive). A cued task-switching paradigm was presented to kindergartners and fourth graders, who are known to differ in their preferential mode of control engagement. Flexibility adaptation was examined through the modulation of switching costs by switch proportion, the so-called list-wide switch proportion (LWSP) effect. When the situation forced the use of reactive control (Experiment 1: simultaneous presentation of the cue and the stimulus), we found the LWSP effect with a greater magnitude in kindergartners than in fourth graders. In the situation inducing proactive control (Experiment 2: task cue presented before and until the stimulus), flexibility adaptation was obtained when error rates were considered but not response times. By demonstrating that even young children are capable of flexibility adaptation to contextual demands, these findings support the hypothesis that implicitly triggered adaptation of control may develop as early as the end of the preschool years despite the immaturity of cognitive control during this period.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "The research explored how children progress in their ability to achieve an ideal equilibrium between being adaptable and maintaining consistency, depending on how often they needed to switch tasks. This exploration was conducted under two distinct conditions that varied in how task switch reconfiguration processes were activated (reactive versus proactive). A task-switching protocol that cues participants was administered to children in kindergarten and fourth grade, distinguished by their preferred operational control styles. The study looked into how flexibility could be adjusted by altering the frequency of task switches, a phenomenon known as the list-wide switch proportion (LWSP) effect. In scenarios that necessitated reactive control (Experiment 1: cue and stimulus presented simultaneously), the LWSP effect was more pronounced in kindergartners compared to fourth graders. Conversely, in conditions favoring proactive control (Experiment 2: task cue displayed before and until presenting the stimulus), adaptability in terms of flexibility was evident through error rates but not through response timings. These results suggest that young children can adapt their flexibility to fit different contexts, indicating that the capacity for implicitly adjusting control can emerge by the late preschool years, even amidst the developmental phase of cognitive control.", "named_entities": ["flexibility", "stability", "reactive vs. proactive", "LWSP effect", "cognitive control"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Management of manure containing veterinary antibiotics is a major concern in anaerobic treatment systems because of their possible adverse effects on microbial communities. Therefore, the aim of study was to investigate how oxytetracycline (OTC) influences bacteria and acetoclastic and hydrogenotrophic methanogens under varying operational conditions in OTC-medicated and non-medicated anaerobic cow manure digesters. Concentrations of OTC and its metabolites throughout the anaerobic digestion were determined using ultraviolet-high-performance liquid chromatography (UV-HPLC) and tandem liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC/MS/MS), respectively. Fluorescent in situ hybridization, denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis, cloning, and sequencing analyses were used to monitor changes in microbial community structures. According to the results of analytical and molecular approaches, operating conditions highly influence active microbial community dynamics and associate with biogas production and elimination of OTC and its metabolites during anaerobic digestion of cow manure in the presence of an average initial concentration of 2.2Â mg OTC/L. The impact of operating conditions has a drastic effect on acetoclastic methanogens than hydrogenotrophic methanogens and bacteria.'

original_corpus: 'Bond strength of hardened plastic teeth or acrylic resin teeth to microwave-curing, conventional heat-curing and 4-META-containing denture base resins were comparatively investigated in this study. Effects of grinding and monomer coating of the tooth ridge lap were also studied. Bond strength of plastic denture teeth to microwave-curing denture base resin was slightly higher than the other two resins. With all denture base resins used, an increased bond strength was obtained with hardened plastic teeth by treatment of tooth ridge lap but not with acrylic resin teeth. However, scattering of the bond strength was reduced by treatment of tooth ridge lap in acrylic resin teeth specimens. With hardened plastic teeth specimens, fracture in the base resin was increased by monomer coating. With acrylic resin teeth specimens, no specific fracture patterns were demonstrated by treatment of tooth ridge lap. Fracture occurred mostly in the acrylic resin teeth. These results suggest that bond strength of both denture teeth to microwave-curing or 4-META-containing denture base resin was increased or solidified by grinding or monomer coating of tooth ridge lap.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "This research extensively explored the bond strength between hardened plastic or acrylic resin denture teeth and three types of denture base resins: microwave-curing, conventional heat-curing, and those containing 4-META. It also assessed the impact of grinding and applying a monomer coat on the tooth ridge lap. It was found that the bond strength to microwave-curing denture base resin was marginally higher compared to the other two resin types. For all denture base resins, an enhancement in bond strength was observed with hardened plastic teeth following tooth ridge lap treatment, a result not replicated with acrylic resin teeth. Nevertheless, the variability in bond strength measurements for acrylic resin teeth was diminished after tooth ridge lap treatment. In cases of hardened plastic teeth, applying a monomer coating led to an increased occurrence of fractures in the base resin. Meanwhile, acrylic resin teeth did not show specific fracture patterns after the tooth ridge lap treatment, with fractures predominantly occurring within the acrylic resin teeth themselves. The findings indicate that the bond strength to both types of denture teeth, regarding microwave-curing or 4-META-containing denture base resins, was enhanced or made more robust by either grinding or applying a monomer coat to the tooth ridge lap.", "named_entities": ["microwave-curing", "conventional heat-curing", "4-META-containing denture base resins", "acrylic resin teeth", "hardened plastic teeth", "monomer coating", "tooth ridge lap"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Five women with multiple sclerosis (MS) and simple urinary stress incontinence were informally evaluated and taught a program of pubococcygeal exercises to determine if inadvertent loss of urine during activities which increase intraabdominal pressure could be improved or eliminated. A correlation seemed to exist between the client's ability to experience vaginal contraction during sexual climax and elimination or improvement of simple urinary stress incontinence using a pubococcygeal exercise program. The purpose of this article is to encourage nurses to consider a pubococcygeal teaching program for treatment of simple urinary stress incontinence in female clients with MS who do experience vaginal contraction during sexual climax.'

original: original_corpus: 'Letitia Fairfield - doctor, lawyer, public health worker, feminist and war worker - was a woman of surprising contradictions. She displayed some eccentric tendencies that sometimes did not sit comfortably with her role as a medical professional; she was, for example, a believer in witchcraft and a convert to Roman Catholicism. However, she made great contributions to medicine throughout her active career and did so during a period in which female access to medical education was limited. Few of her female or male peers received such respect or oversaw such change. Despite pushing contemporary professional boundaries and reaching a level of seniority unusual for female doctors of her era, however, Letitia was, whether through choice or through convention, channelled into traditionally female areas of medicine. Thus, her medical success arguably was due not only to her motivation and capability but also because she represented no real competition to men.'

original_corpus: 'Visceral leishmaniasis, a chronic, potentially fatal disease, is characterized by high production of low-affinity antibodies. In humans, hypergammaglobulinemia is prediction of disease progression. Nevertheless, the contribution of hypermutated and/or class-switched immunoglobulins to disease pathogenesis has never been studied. Using Aicda<sup>-/-</sup> mice and the experimental model of Leishmania donovani infection, we demonstrate that the absence of hypermutated and/or class-switched antibodies was associated with increased resistance to disease, stronger protective Th1 responses, and a lower frequency of regulatory IFNγ<sup>+</sup> IL-10<sup>+</sup> CD4 T cells. Interestingly, stronger Th1 responses and the absence of IFNγ<sup>+</sup> IL-10<sup>+</sup> CD4 T cells during chronic infection in infected Aicda<sup>-/-</sup> mice were not caused by a T-cell intrinsic effect of AID, but by changes in the cytokine environment during chronic disease. Indeed TNF, IL-10 and IFN-ß expressions were only upregulated in the presence of hypermutated, class-switched antibodies and hypergammaglobulinemia at later stages of infection. Taken together, our results suggest that hypergammaglobulinemia sustains inhibitory responses during chronic visceral leishmaniasis.'

Research using Aicda-/- mice in the context of Leishmania donovani infection revealed that the lack of hypermutated and/or class-switched antibodies led to better resistance against the disease, enhanced Th1 protective responses, and fewer regulatory IFNÎ³+ IL-10+ CD4 T cells. Notably, the improved Th1 responses and the reduced presence of IFNÎ³+ IL-10+ CD4 T cells in chronically infected Aicda-/- mice were not due to a direct effect on T-cells by AID but were attributed to alterations in the cytokine milieu during the course of the disease. Specifically, TNF, IL-10, and IFN-Î² levels were elevated only in the presence of hypermutated, class-switched antibodies and high levels of gamma globulins at the disease's later stages. Our findings indicate that high levels of gamma globulins perpetuate suppressive reactions throughout the chronic phase of visceral leishmaniasis.",

original: original_corpus: 'O'Brien and Fleming (1979, Biometrics 35, 549-556) proposed a procedure for multiple testing in clinical trials for acute disease. We evaluated their procedure for chronic-disease models and found that it can be used without modification. Type I errors are unaltered and no loss of power is seen in comparison with single-sample procedures. However, average savings in sample size are less for the chronic-disease models than for the acute model. Finally, it is shown that for any specific disease model and fixed maximum number of inspections of the data, the percentage reduction in sample size can be readily predicted from the power.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "O'Brien and Fleming, in their 1979 article in Biometrics, introduced a method for conducting multiple tests in clinical studies focused on acute diseases. Our analysis of this method for chronic disease scenarios indicates that it can be applied directly without any alterations. The likelihood of Type I errors remains unchanged, and there is no observable decrease in effectiveness compared to procedures that use a single sample. Nevertheless, the reduction in the number of participants required is generally smaller for chronic conditions than for acute ones. It is also demonstrated that the expected decrease in sample size for any given disease study, assuming a set maximum number of data reviews, can be accurately estimated based on the statistical power of the study.", "named_entities": ["O'Brien and Fleming", "1979", "Biometrics", "Type I errors", "chronic-disease models", "acute disease"]}

The morbidity level in the control group corresponded to the predicted value and exceeded the morbidity level in the vaccinated group 4.2-fold. The conclusion was made on the effectiveness of immunoprophylaxis.'

original: original_corpus: 'Segregated-network carbon nanotube (CNT)-polymer composites were prepared, and their thermoelectric properties were measured as a function of CNT concentration at room temperature. This study shows that electrical conductivity can be dramatically increased by creating a network of CNTs in the composite, while the thermal conductivity and thermopower remain relatively insensitive to the filler concentration. This behavior results from thermally disconnected, but electrically connected, junctions in the nanotube network, which makes it feasible to tune the properties in favor of a higher thermoelectric figure of merit. With a CNT concentration of 20 wt %, these composites exhibit an electrical conductivity of 4800 S/m, thermal conductivity of 0.34 W/m x K and a thermoelectric figure of merit (ZT) greater than 0.006 at room temperature. This study suggests that polymeric thermoelectrics are possible and provides the basis for further development of lightweight, low-cost, and nontoxic polymer composites for thermoelectric applications in the future.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Composites of carbon nanotube (CNT)-polymer with segregated networks were synthesized, and their thermoelectric characteristics were evaluated at ambient temperature as a function of the CNT content. The findings reveal that the electrical conductivity of the composites can be significantly enhanced by forming a CNT network within the material, while the thermal conductivity and Seebeck coefficient (thermopower) show little or no change with varying amounts of CNT filler. This phenomenon is attributed to the formation of junctions within the nanotube network that are thermally isolated but maintain electrical continuity, allowing for the adjustment of the composite's properties to improve its thermoelectric efficiency. At a CNT loading of 20 wt %, these materials demonstrated an electrical conductivity of 4800 S/m, a thermal conductivity of 0.34 W/mK, and a thermoelectric figure of merit (ZT) exceeding 0.006 at room temperature. The study indicates the viability of using polymeric materials for thermoelectric devices and lays the groundwork for the future development of lightweight, affordable, and environmentally friendly polymer-based composites for thermoelectric uses.", "named_entities": ["carbon nanotube (CNT)-polymer composites", "electrical conductivity", "thermal conductivity", "thermopower", "thermoelectric figure of merit (ZT)"]}

original: original_corpus: 'A total of 128 bovine and 134 human group B streptococci were serotyped by conventional methods. Among the bovine cultures, 60 (47%) had type antigen X, and among the human cultures, 53 (39%) had type antigen R. The occurrence of type antigens X and R was significantly related to the growth pattern of the bacteria in fluid media. Type X- and R-positive cultures and most of the nontypeable cultures predominantly formed long chains and grew as granular sediment with clear supernatant. In addition, group B streptococci with surface antigen X or R showed compact colony formation in soft agar and reacted positively in the salt aggregation test. These properties, possibly caused by the surface charges of the X- and R-positive cultures, might be related to bacterial pathogenicity.'

original_corpus: 'Psychoactive substances are ubiquitous in the environment at low concentrations, and tobacco, cannabis, etc. are all widely-existing examples. Given their potent biological activity, psychoactive substances are suspected to be harmful to the environment, and reports of their ecological risks are gradually increasing. Since the 1990s, the investigations into psychoactive substances have made remarkable progress, yet some research fields still need to be modernised. For example, the unification of standardised analytical methods as well as the supplementation of occurrence literature. In addition, a relatively lagging risk evaluation system caused by a lack of toxicity data is particularly in need of improvement. The purpose of this article is to develop a review of current research on psychoactive substances, including analytical methods, distribution in environmental compartments, and ecological risk assessment, as well as to point out deficiencies and development prospects and to offer motivation for enhancing the research level in this field.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Psychoactive compounds are found everywhere in the environment at minimal levels, with substances like tobacco and cannabis being common examples. Due to their strong biological effects, there is growing concern about their potential environmental harm, with increasing evidence of their ecological dangers. Research on psychoactive substances has advanced significantly since the 1990s, but some areas still require updates, such as harmonizing analytical techniques and expanding the body of research on their presence. Furthermore, the evaluation of ecological risks is hindered by insufficient toxicity information, highlighting an urgent need for improvement. This article aims to provide an overview of the current state of research on psychoactive compounds, covering methods of analysis, their environmental distribution, and assessments of their ecological risks. It also identifies gaps in knowledge and future directions for research, with the goal of encouraging more sophisticated study in this area.", "named_entities": ["Psychoactive substances", "tobacco", "cannabis", "ecological risks", "toxicity data", "ecological risk assessment"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Human VÎ³2VÎ´2 (also termed VÎ³9VÎ´2) T cells play important roles in microbial and tumor immunity by monitoring foreign- and self-prenyl pyrophosphate metabolites in isoprenoid biosynthesis. Accumulation of isoprenoid metabolites after bisphosphonate treatment allows VÎ³2VÎ´2 T cells to recognize and kill tumors independently of their MHC expression or burden of non-synonymous mutations. Clinical trials with more than 400 patients show that adoptive immunotherapy with VÎ³2VÎ´2Â T cells has few side effects but has resulted in only a few partial and complete remissions. Here, we have tested VÎ³2VÎ´2Â T cells for expression of inhibitory receptors and determined whether adding PD-1 checkpoint blockade to adoptively transferred VÎ³2VÎ´2Â T cells enhances immunity to human PC-3 prostate tumors in an NSG mouse model. We find that VÎ³2VÎ´2 T cells express PD-1, CTLA-4, LAG-3, and TIM-3 inhibitory receptors during the 14-day ex vivo expansion period, and PD-1, LAG-3, and TIM-3 upon subsequent stimulation by pamidronate-treated tumor cells.
