The left hips served as the control group. At the age of two months, 15 of the surviving rabbits were euthanized and their hips examined both macroscopically and microscopically, and another 14 rabbits underwent the same process at four months old. The findings indicated that in approximately half of the rabbits at two months and in all of the rabbits at four months, the articular cartilage of the acetabulum in the dislocated hips exhibited signs of fibrous degeneration. Conversely, the articular cartilage in the dislocated femoral heads appeared normal, with fibrous degeneration observed in just 25% of the animals at four months of age.", "named_entities": ["articular cartilage", "acetabulum", "fibrous degeneration"]}

original: original_corpus: 'The basic structural characterization of complex I is still not trivial due to its complexity, not only in the number of its protein constituents but especially because of the different properties of the several subunits. Bacterial complex I generally contains 14 subunits: 7 hydrophilic proteins located in the peripheral arm and 7 hydrophobic proteins present in the membrane arm. It is the identification of the hydrophobic proteins that makes the characterization of complex I, and of membrane proteins in general, very difficult. In this article, we report the identification of the subunits of complex I from Rhodothermus marinus. The original approach, presented here, combined several protein and peptides separation strategies (different reversed phase materials, high-performance liquid chromatography, and gel electrophoresis) with different identification methods (electrospray ionization-tandem mass spectrometry, matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization-time-of-flight mass spectrometry, and Edman degradation analysis) and represents a step forward in the characterization of membrane proteins that studies are still technically highly challenging. The combination of the different methodologies allowed the identification of complex I canonical subunits and also a possible novel subunit, namely a pterin-4Î±-carbinolamine dehydratase (PCD). This was the first time that a PCD was suggested to be part of complex I, and its possible regulatory role is discussed.'

The hydrophobic proteins, in particular, pose significant difficulties in the detailed study of complex I, as well as membrane proteins in general. In our work, we detail the process of identifying the subunits of complex I from Rhodothermus marinus. Our novel approach integrates multiple strategies for protein and peptide separation (such as various reversed phase materials, high-performance liquid chromatography, and gel electrophoresis) with several identification techniques (including electrospray ionization-tandem mass spectrometry, matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization-time-of-flight mass spectrometry, and Edman degradation analysis). This method marks an advancement in the study of membrane proteins, which remains exceptionally demanding technically. By utilizing a combination of these methodologies, we were able to not only identify the canonical subunits of complex I but also discover a potentially new subunit, specifically a pterin-4Î±-carbinolamine dehydratase (PCD). original: original_corpus: 'We study the effect of a non-Gaussian noise on interstate switching activated primarily by Gaussian noise. Even weak non-Gaussian noise can strongly change the switching rate. The effect is determined by all moments of the noise distribution. It is expressed in a closed form in terms of the noise characteristic functional. The analytical results are compared with the results of simulations for an overdamped system driven by white Gaussian noise and a Poisson noise. Switching induced by a purely Poisson noise is also discussed.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Our research investigates how non-Gaussian noise influences the rate of switching between states, a process mainly triggered by Gaussian noise. Remarkably, even minimal non-Gaussian noise can significantly alter the switching frequency. This impact is influenced by the complete range of the noise distribution's moments and is concisely described using the noise's characteristic functional. We compare our theoretical findings with simulation outcomes for a system experiencing overdamping, propelled by white Gaussian noise alongside Poisson noise. The scenario of switching purely due to Poisson noise is further examined.", "named_entities": ["non-Gaussian noise", "Gaussian noise", "noise distribution", "characteristic functional", "overdamped system", "white Gaussian noise", "Poisson noise"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Camptothecin (CPT), a broad-spectrum anticancer drug, has been extensively used clinically. However, its hydrophobic properties seriously hinder its antitumor therapeutic effect. Herein, we synthesized acid-degradable Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>@poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>@PVP)/gold nanoclusters@zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 composite nanoparticles (ZIF-8CNPs) via a facile method and utilized them as carriers to efficiently load CPT. The excellent fluorescence properties of gold nanoclusters (AuNCs) and the photothermal properties of Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>@poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>@PVP) endowed the nanocomposites with excellent cell imaging and photothermal functions. In addition, the surface modification of the composite nanoparticles with folic acid-grafted bovine serum albumin (FA-BSA) enables them to efficiently target tumor cells. Once FA-BSA/ZIF-8CNPs-CPT are taken up by tumor cells and irradiated with a near-infrared laser, the nanoparticles show a highly effective inhibitory effect against various tumor cells through a chemo-photothermal synergistic effect. Hence, it is conceivable that this acid-responsive multifunctional ZIF-8 nanocomposite has promising bioapplication prospects in cancer treatment.'

{
  "paraphrase_corpus": "Camptothecin (CPT), a widely used anticancer agent, faces challenges in clinical application due to its hydrophobic nature, which limits its effectiveness against tumors. To overcome this, we developed a straightforward synthesis method for acid-degradable composite nanoparticles made of Fe3O4@poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (Fe3O4@PVP)/gold nanoclusters embedded in a zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8CNPs). These nanoparticles were designed to carry CPT efficiently. The inclusion of gold nanoclusters grants the nanoparticles exceptional fluorescence capabilities for cell imaging, while the Fe3O4@PVP component provides photothermal features. Moreover, coating the nanoparticles with folic acid-modified bovine serum albumin (FA-BSA) enhances their ability to specifically target cancer cells. Upon exposure to near-infrared light, the FA-BSA/ZIF-8CNPs-CPT nanoparticles demonstrate a potent ability to suppress tumor cells via a combined chemo-photothermal therapy. This innovative ZIF-8 nanocomposite, responsive to acidic conditions, holds significant potential for advanced cancer treatment strategies.",

original: original_corpus: 'In this study, by the generation of a specific monoclonal antibody, we identified p75/AIRM1 (for adhesion inhibitory receptor molecule 1), a novel inhibitory receptor that is mostly confined to human natural killer cells. p75/AIRM1 is a 75-kD glycoprotein that, upon sodium pervanadate treatment, becomes tyrosine phosphorylated and associates to src homology 2 domain-bearing protein tyrosine phosphatase (SHP)-1. The p75/AIRM1 gene is located on human chromosome 19 and encodes a novel member of the sialoadhesin family characterized by three immunoglobulin-like extracellular domains (one NH(2)-terminal V-type and two C2-type) and a classical immunoreceptor tyrosine-based inhibitory motif (ITIM) in the cytoplasmic portion. The highest amino acid sequence similarity has been found with the myeloid-specific CD33 molecule and the placental CD33L1 protein. Similar to other sialoadhesin molecules, p75/AIRM1 appears to mediate sialic acid-dependent ligand recognition.'

original: original_corpus: 'Computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging are routinely used during follow-up of radiofrequency ablation (RFA) of renal masses. Widespread acceptance of needle ablation is limited by the need to rely on radiographic criteria to confirm effective ablation. In this report, we correlated the long-term radiographic appearance of RFA with the histologic findings in three delayed nephrectomy specimens. This should enhance our understanding of the histopathologic features of successful RFA and highlight potential shortcomings of modern imaging after ablation.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Routine follow-ups for radiofrequency ablation (RFA) of kidney masses often involve the use of computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging. The broad approval of needle ablation is hindered by the requirement to depend on radiographic standards for verifying successful ablation. In this study, we compared the extended radiographic outcomes of RFA with histologic results from three nephrectomy specimens obtained later. This comparison aims to improve our grasp of the histopathologic characteristics indicative of effective RFA and to point out possible limitations of contemporary imaging techniques post-ablation.", "named_entities": ["Computed tomography", "magnetic resonance imaging", "radiofrequency ablation", "RFA", "radiographic criteria", "histologic findings", "nephrectomy specimens"]}

original: original_corpus: 'In 19 wheat-milling fractions total pentosan content, calculated as 0.88 x (% L-arabinose + % D-xylose), varied between 1.44 and 30.66% on dry matter (dm). It increased with ash content once the latter exceeded 0.6% (dm basis). Water-extractable arabinoxylans were recovered by saturating water extracts to 65% ethanol. Their contents in the milling fractions varied between 0.35 and 1.38%, and above 0.6% ash content also increased with this parameter. Their L-arabinose-to-D-xylose ratios ranged between 0.65 and 0.39, with the lowest values found for the fractions with highest ash content, indicating that the ash-rich tissues contain more arabinoxylans that are less branched. (1)H NMR spectroscopy revealed that the decrease in L-arabinose-to-D-xylose ratio was accompanied by an increase in unsubstituted xylose residues and a decrease in disubstituted xylose residues, while the contents of monosubstituted xyloses were virtually constant.'

original_corpus: 'A methodology is described for analysing the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) in terms of molecular conformations. Molecular species that have more than a single occurrence across the complete CSD are identified, either as the sole crystal component or co-crystallized with other components. Cluster analysis, based on a root-mean-square fit of coordinates and chemical connectivity, is performed to identify conformational variance for each molecule. Results are analysed in terms of the number of discrete conformations observed versus the number of crystal environments and number of acyclic torsion angles in the molecule. Special subsets of environments are also analysed, namely polymorphs, co-crystals and solvates. In general, conformational diversity increases with an increasing number of different crystal environments and with an increasing number of flexible torsion angles. Overall, molecules with one or more acyclic flexible torsion angle are observed to exist in more than one conformation in ca 40% of cases. There is evidence that solvated molecules exhibit more conformational flexibility on average, compared with polymorphs and co-crystals.'

original_corpus: 'Extracellular signal-regulated kinase 8 (ERK8), proposed as a novel potential therapeutic target for cancer, has been implicated in cell transformation, apoptosis, the protection of genomic integrity, and autophagy. To facilitate ERK8 research, a highly specific anti-ERK8 antibody is needed. In this article, we use the Immune Epitope Database and Analysis Resource online tool to predict B-cell epitopes of human ERK8 protein, and choose a 28 aa-peptide sequence to generate the GST-ERK8(28aa) fusion protein as the antigen for developing polyclonal antibody against ERK8. The specificity and sensitivity of anti-ERK8 antibody were robustly validated by immunoblotting, immunocytochemical and immunohistochemical analyses; and we found that both the endogenous and ectopically-expressed human ERK8 proteins can be recognized by our anti-ERK8 antibody. This suggested that our characterized anti-ERK8 antibody will be a valuable tool for the elucidation of the distribution of ERK8 at cellular and histological levels. Finally, our tissue array analysis also demonstrated that the ERK8 protein was localized in both the nucleus and cytoplasm of human lung cancers.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "ERK8, identified as a promising new target for cancer treatment, plays a role in cellular transformation, apoptosis, maintaining genomic stability, and autophagy. To advance research on ERK8, there is a necessity for an anti-ERK8 antibody with high specificity. In this study, we employed the Immune Epitope Database and Analysis Resource online platform to identify B-cell epitopes of the human ERK8 protein. A 28 amino acid peptide sequence was selected for synthesizing the GST-ERK8(28aa) fusion protein, which served as the antigen to produce a polyclonal antibody targeting ERK8. The anti-ERK8 antibody's specificity and sensitivity were rigorously confirmed through immunoblotting, immunocytochemistry, and immunohistochemistry, revealing its ability to detect both naturally occurring and artificially introduced human ERK8 proteins. The findings indicate that the developed anti-ERK8 antibody is an effective tool for studying ERK8's distribution within cells and across tissue samples. original: original_corpus: 'The aim of the study was to improve the pre-operative diagnosis of mammary mucinous lesions. All mucinous lesions detected by fine needle aspiration (FNA) and confirmed by histological examination were reviewed by cytological findings, mammographic appearances and sonographic findings. Twenty aspirates had corresponding pathology, including 12 mucinous carcinomas, two mucocele-like lesions (MLL) with atypical ductal hyperplasia, three MLL with ductal hyperplasia and three simple MLL. Simple MLL and mucocele-like with ductal hyperplasia showed scant cellularity, no or rare intact single tumour cells, monolayered arrangement and absence of nuclear atypia. In contrast, most mucinous carcinomas showed higher cellularity, more single tumour cells, three-dimensional clusters, and mild to marked nuclear atypia. However, MLL with atypical ductal hyperplasia showed cytological features overlapping with mucinous carcinoma. MLL had a non-specific mammographic appearance and showed a cystic lesion on sonography. Mucinous carcinoma appeared as a solid mass on sonography and as a distinct nodule on mammography. Based on the combination of FNA cytology and image findings, benign MLL can be correctly distinguished from mucinous carcinoma before surgery.'

Simple MLLs and those with ductal hyperplasia were characterized by low cellularity, the scarcity or absence of intact single tumor cells, a monolayered structure, and no nuclear atypia. On the other hand, mucinous carcinomas typically exhibited increased cellularity, numerous single tumor cells, three-dimensional cell clusters, and varying degrees of nuclear atypia. MLL with atypical ductal hyperplasia displayed cytological characteristics that could be confused with those of mucinous carcinoma. MLLs presented with an indistinct appearance on mammograms and were identified as cystic lesions via ultrasound. original: original_corpus: 'Malignant mesenchymoma within the right ulnar nerve of an 8 year old boy is described. The patient did not have stigmata of von Recklinghausen's neurofibromatosis. The growing and painful tumour was excised five and a half detection, and recurred five months later. Mingling of the nerve sheath sarcoma and rhabdomyosarcoma was noted within the same mass which was separated from the adjacent striated muscles. It is suggested that this mesenchymoma arose from mesenchymal cells or cells of mesenchymal type comprising the peripheral nerve sheath which is derived from ectomesenchyme of the neural crest.'

The tumor, which was growing and causing pain, was removed approximately five and a half years after its detection, but it reappeared five months after surgery. The tumor was a mix of nerve sheath sarcoma and rhabdomyosarcoma, distinctly isolated from the neighboring striated muscles. original: original_corpus: 'The response of human and bovine peripheral blood lymphocytes to PHA stimulation was measured in the presence of low concentrations of sodium arsenite and sodium arsenate. In bovine lymphocytes, 41% augmentation of the response occurred at 10(-6) M arsenite with a return to the normal response at 2.5 X 10(-6) M. Complete inhibition of mitogenesis occurred at 6 X 10(-6) M. In the presence of sodium arsenate, similar results were obtained but at the higher concentrations of 2 X 10(-5) (for 57% augmentation), 5.2 X 10(-5), and 1.9 X 10(-4) M, respectively. The possible significance of these findings in view of the known relationship between chronic arsenicalism and human skin cancer is discussed. It is suggested that arsenic compounds may, by potentiating mitogenesis, increase the possibility of errors in DNA replication, some of which could be potentially carcinogenic. Additionally, interference with the immune response could enable potentially cancerous cells to escape immune surveillance.'

{
  "paraphrase_corpus": "The reaction of human and cow peripheral blood lymphocytes to PHA stimulation was assessed in the context of low doses of sodium arsenite and sodium arsenate. For cow lymphocytes, a 41% enhancement in reaction was seen at 10(-6) M of arsenite, returning to a baseline response at 2.5 X 10(-6) M. Mitogenesis was completely halted at 6 X 10(-6) M. With sodium arsenate, analogous outcomes were achieved, though at higher concentrations of 2 X 10(-5) (leading to a 57% enhancement), 5.2 X 10(-5), and 1.9 X 10(-4) M. The implications of these results are explored, considering the established link between prolonged exposure to arsenic and the incidence of human skin cancer. It is proposed that compounds of arsenic might enhance mitogenesis, thereby raising the risk of DNA replication errors, some of which might be carcinogenic. Moreover, the disturbance of immune responses might allow potentially cancerous cells to evade detection by the body's immune system.",

original: original_corpus: 'Right-angle dual-headed tomography has increased cardiac SPECT utility by cutting acquisition time in half which enhances gating capabilities. When gating, however, a deceleration in heart rate, due to a return to baseline rate after stress or lessened anxiety at the end of a study, may significantly affect the last step(s) of a gated study with possible frame or information loss. The purpose of this study was to illustrate the artifacts produced in myocardial perfusion studies when a frame or frames are lost in single- and dual-detector SPECT imaging methodologies.'

original_corpus: 'The photoluminescence properties of 9,9-bis[4'-(9''-carbazovinylene)phenyl]fluorene (F-CZV) formed by Heck reaction of 9,9-bis(4'-iodophenyl)fluorene (F-IP) and N-vinylcarbazole have been carefully studied. The results show that the compound emits blue light and the dimolecular excimer is formed with gradual increase in concentration of F-CZV. The results also indicate the interaction between F-CZV and electron donors (N,N-dimethylaniline) or electron acceptors (dimethylterephthalate, fullerene carbon nanotubes) can be efficiently generated where the processes follow the Stern-Volmer equation. Moreover, when dimethylterephthalate (DMTP) or carbon nanotubes (CNTs) is gradually added into the solution of F-CZV, the emission intensities of fluorescence are unusually increased. But when concentration of dimethylterephthalate or carbon nanotubes beyond a certain scope, the emission intensities of fluorescence are gradually decreased.'

original: original_corpus: 'Human B lymphocytes have been shown to have at least five polymorphic specificities defined by 32 antisera. The antisera were produced by absorption with pooled platelets to remove HLA activity and were selected out of over 400 tested sera. The sera that defined the five specificities had high correlation coefficients within a group (generally in the range of 0.6-0.9). As shown by the fit in the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, the five specificities appear to be determined by alleles at one genetic locus. No association between these specificities and HLA was noted.'

These antisera were obtained through the process of absorption with pooled platelets to eliminate HLA activity, and were chosen from a total of over 400 sera that were tested. The sera responsible for identifying the five specificities showed strong correlation within each group, typically ranging from 0.6 to 0.9. According to the fit with the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, these specificities seem to be governed by alleles at a single genetic locus. There was no observed link between these specificities and HLA.", "named_entities": ["Human B lymphocytes", "polymorphic specificities", "antisera", "HLA", "Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium", "alleles", "genetic locus"]}

original: original_corpus: '2-Alkoxycarbonylazolium N-aminides are interesting species, as they have the potential to act as efficient 1,4-dipole equivalents when they react with heterocumulenes, such as iso(thio)cyanates and carbodiimides. These reactions give heterobetaines containing the imidazo[2,1-f][1,2,4]triazinium system, in a formal [4 + 2] cyclocondensation process. These N-aminides, however, can also behave as 1,3-dipoles when they react with isocyanates to afford a cycloadduct that, depending on the position of alkoxycarbonyl group, can undergo a reversion process or a ring expansion to the more stable heterobetaine system.'

These interactions result in the creation of heterobetaines that feature the imidazo[2,1-f][1,2,4]triazinium system, through a formal [4 + 2] cyclocondensation mechanism. Nonetheless, these N-aminides can also act as 1,3-dipoles in their reactions with isocyanates, leading to a cycloadduct which, based on the positioning of the alkoxycarbonyl group, might either revert to its original state or expand into a ring, forming a more stable heterobetaine structure.", "named_entities": ["2-Alkoxycarbonylazolium N-aminides", "heterocumulenes", "iso(thio)cyanates", "carbodiimides", "heterobetaines", "imidazo[2,1-f][1,2,4]triazinium", "cyclocondensation", "isocyanates"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Chicken histone H5 is an H1-like linker histone that is expressed only in nucleated erythrocytes. The histone H5 promoter has binding sites for Sp1 (a high affinity site) and UPE-binding protein, while the 3' erythroid-specific enhancer has binding sites for Sp1 (one moderate and three weak affinity), GATA-1, and NF1. In this study we investigated whether trans-acting factors that bind to the chicken histone H5 promoter or enhancer are associated with adult chicken immature and mature erythrocyte nuclear matrices. We show that NF1, but not Sp1, GATA-1, or UPE-binding protein, is associated with the internal nuclear matrices of these erythroid cells. Further, we found that a subset of the NF1 family of proteins is bound to the mature erythrocyte nuclear matrix. These results suggest that in chicken erythrocytes NF1 may mediate an interaction between the histone H5 enhancer and the erythroid internal nuclear matrix. NF1 was also present in the internal nuclear matrices of chicken liver and trout liver. The observations of this study provide evidence that NF1 may have a role in a variety of cell types in targeting specific DNA sequences to the nuclear matrix.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Chicken histone H5, resembling the H1 linker histone, is uniquely produced in nucleated erythrocytes. The promoter of histone H5 contains binding regions for Sp1 (with one high affinity site) and UPE-binding protein, whereas its 3' erythroid-specific enhancer includes sites for Sp1 (with one moderate and three low affinity sites), GATA-1, and NF1. This research aimed to determine if trans-acting factors interacting with the chicken histone H5 promoter or enhancer are connected with the nuclear matrices of adult chicken erythrocytes, both immature and mature. The findings revealed that among the factors, only NF1 is linked with the internal nuclear matrices in these erythroid cells. Additionally, it was observed that a specific group within the NF1 protein family attaches to the nuclear matrix of mature erythrocytes. These results indicate the potential role of NF1 in facilitating communications between the histone H5 enhancer and the internal nuclear structure of erythroid cells. Notably, NF1's presence was also detected in the internal nuclear matrices of both chicken and trout livers. These findings underscore the possibility that NF1 might play a crucial part across various cell types in guiding specific DNA sequences to the nuclear matrix.", "named_entities": ["Chicken histone H5", "Sp1", "UPE-binding protein", "GATA-1", "NF1", "erythrocyte nuclear matrices", "nuclear matrix"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Optimisation of radiation protection in fluoroscopy is important since the procedure could lead to relatively high absorbed doses both in patients and personnel resulting in acute radiation injury. Optimisation procedures include adjustment of the fluoroscopy equipment such as exposure factors as well as proper use of automatic brightness control and pulsed fluoroscopy. It is also important to gain the benefits of image processing and the higher sensitivity of flat panel detectors as compared to image intensifier-TV systems.Proper positioning of the patient with respect to detector and X-ray tube is of fundamental importance to image quality and radiation dose to the patient. Both image quality and radiation dose are also affected by the methodology used with parameters such as magnification factor, increased filtration, use of last-image-hold and the use of a grid.There is a direct relation between patient dose and the absorbed dose to the personnel since this is mostly due to scattered radiation from the patient. If the correct methodology and the correct radiation protection devices are used, the absorbed dose to the personnel could be minimised to acceptable levels even for those working with complex procedures.In order to have an organised review of all aspects of optimisation, it is recommendable to have an active quality system at the department. This system should define responsibilities and tasks for persons involved.'
output: {"paraphrase_corpus": "Enhancing radiation safety in fluoroscopy is crucial as the procedure can result in significant radiation doses to both patients and medical staff, potentially causing acute radiation damage. The optimisation strategies involve adjusting fluoroscopy settings, such as exposure levels, and ensuring the effective use of automatic brightness control and pulsed fluoroscopy techniques. Leveraging the advancements in image processing technology and the superior sensitivity of flat panel detectors over traditional image intensifier-TV setups is also key. Correct patient positioning in relation to the detector and the X-ray source is essential for maximizing image quality and minimizing radiation exposure to the patient. Factors such as magnification levels, additional filtration, the employment of last-image-hold features, and the use of grids also play a critical role in balancing image quality with radiation dose. The radiation dose received by medical personnel is directly linked to the patient's dose since it predominantly originates from radiation scattered off the patient. By adopting proper techniques and radiation shielding devices, the exposure to staff can be greatly reduced to safe levels, even during complex procedures. To systematically address all facets of optimisation, it is advisable to implement a comprehensive quality management system within the radiology department. Such a system would outline specific responsibilities and tasks for all involved personnel.", "named_entities": ["fluoroscopy", "automatic brightness control", "pulsed fluoroscopy", "flat panel detectors", "image intensifier-TV systems", "magnification factor", "last-image-hold", "grid"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Androgens are critical for normal prostate development and function, as well as prostate cancer initiation and progression. Androgens function mainly by regulating target gene expression through the androgen receptor (AR). Many studies have shown that androgen-AR signaling exerts actions on key events during prostate carcinogenesis. In this review, androgen action in distinct aspects of prostate carcinogenesis, including (i) cell proliferation, (ii) cell apoptosis, and (iii) prostate cancer metastasis will be discussed.'

They primarily exert their effects by modulating the expression of specific genes via the androgen receptor (AR). Numerous research findings indicate that the androgen-AR pathway influences critical processes in the development of prostate cancer. This overview will cover the effects of androgen on various facets of prostate cancer development, namely (i) cell growth, (ii) cell death, and (iii) the spread of prostate cancer.", "named_entities": ["Androgens", "prostate cancer", "androgen receptor (AR)", "prostate carcinogenesis", "cell proliferation", "cell apoptosis", "prostate cancer metastasis"]}

original: original_corpus: 'Quality underlies diverse efforts to repair the troubled health care system, yet the many abstract definitions offered are not particularly useful. A better approach is to evaluate quality in an applied or situational context. This article offers six propositions that establish such a context and explain why the current health care environment is so volatile. Some parallels between health care and the emerging field of science called chaos theory are drawn as a possible future basis for recognizing order in the health care system.'

However, the various abstract explanations provided do not serve practical purposes well. It is more effective to assess quality within a specific or situational framework. This piece presents six assertions that create this framework and shed light on the reasons behind the current volatile nature of the health care environment. It also makes comparisons between health care and the new scientific area known as chaos theory, suggesting this could be a future method for identifying organization within the health care system.", "named_entities": ["quality", "health care system", "chaos theory"]}
